german: Der Mensch besitzt die Fähigkeit Sprachen zu bauen, womit sich jeder Sinn ausdrücken lässt, ohne eine Ahnung davon zu haben, wie und was jedes Wort bedeutet. – Wie man auch spricht, ohne zu wissen, wie die einzelnen Laute hervorgebracht werden.
english_ogden: Man possesses the capacity of constructing languages, in which every sense can be expressed, without having an idea how and what each word means—just as one speaks without knowing how the single sounds are produced.
english_pears: Man possesses the ability to construct languages capable of expressing every sense, without having any idea how each word has meaning or what its meaning is—just as people speak without knowing how the individual sounds are produced.

text: 4.003 Most of the propositions and questions to be found in philosophical works are not false but nonsensical. Consequently we cannot give any answer to questions of this kind, but can only point out that they are nonsensical. Most of the propositions and questions of philosophers arise from our failure to understand the logic of our language.
german: Die meisten Sätze und Fragen, welche über philosophische Dinge geschrieben worden sind, sind nicht falsch, sondern unsinnig. Wir können daher Fragen dieser Art überhaupt nicht beantworten, sondern nur ihre Unsinnigkeit feststellen. Die meisten Fragen und Sätze der Philosophen beruhen darauf, dass wir unsere Sprachlogik nicht verstehen.
english_ogden: Most propositions and questions, that have been written about philosophical matters, are not false, but senseless. We cannot, therefore, answer questions of this kind at all, but only state their senselessness. Most questions and propositions of the philosophers result from the fact that we do not understand the logic of our language.
english_pears: Most of the propositions and questions to be found in philosophical works are not false but nonsensical. Consequently we cannot give any answer to questions of this kind, but can only point out that they are nonsensical. Most of the propositions and questions of philosophers arise from our failure to understand the logic of our language.

text: 4.0031 All philosophy is a ‘critique of language’ (though not in Mauthner’s sense). It was Russell who performed the service of showing that the apparent logical form of a proposition need not be its real one.
german: Alle Philosophie ist „Sprachkritik“. (Allerdings nicht im Sinne Mauthners.) Russells Verdienst ist es, gezeigt zu haben, dass die scheinbare logische Form des Satzes nicht seine wirkliche sein muss.
english_ogden: All philosophy is “Critique of language” (but not at all in Mauthner’s sense). Russell’s merit is to have shown that the apparent logical form of the proposition need not be its real form.
english_pears: All philosophy is a ‘critique of language’ (though not in Mauthner’s sense). It was Russell who performed the service of showing that the apparent logical form of a proposition need not be its real one.

text: 4.01 A proposition is a picture of reality.
german: Der Satz ist ein Bild der Wirklichkeit.
english_ogden: The proposition is a picture of reality.
english_pears: A proposition is a picture of reality.

text: 4.011 At first sight a proposition—one set out on the printed page, for example—does not seem to be a picture of the reality with which it is concerned. But neither do written notes seem at first sight to be a picture of a piece of music, nor our phonetic notation (the alphabet) to be a picture of our speech.
german: Auf den ersten Blick scheint der Satz – wie er etwa auf dem Papier gedruckt steht – kein Bild der Wirklichkeit zu sein, von der er handelt. Aber auch die Notenschrift scheint auf den ersten Blick kein Bild der Musik zu sein, und unsere Lautzeichen-(Buchstaben-)Schrift kein Bild unserer Lautsprache.
english_ogden: At the first glance the proposition—say as it stands printed on paper—does not seem to be a picture of the reality of which it treats. But nor does the musical score appear at first sight to be a picture of a musical piece; nor does our phonetic spelling (letters) seem to be a picture of our spoken language.
english_pears: At first sight a proposition—one set out on the printed page, for example—does not seem to be a picture of the reality with which it is concerned. But neither do written notes seem at first sight to be a picture of a piece of music, nor our phonetic notation (the alphabet) to be a picture of our speech.

text: 4.012 It is obvious that a proposition of the form ‘aRb’ strikes us as a picture. In this case the sign is obviously a likeness of what is signified.
german: Offenbar ist, dass wir einen Satz von der Form „aRb“ als Bild empfinden. Hier ist das Zeichen offenbar ein Gleichnis des Bezeichneten.
english_ogden: It is obvious that we perceive a proposition of the form aRb as a picture. Here the sign is obviously a likeness of the signified.
english_pears: It is obvious that a proposition of the form ‘aRb’ strikes us as a picture. In this case the sign is obviously a likeness of what is signified.

text: 4.013 And if we penetrate to the essence of this pictorial character, we see that it is not impaired by apparent irregularities (such as the use of ♯ and ♭ in musical notation).
german: Und wenn wir in das Wesentliche dieser Bildhaftigkeit eindringen, so sehen wir, dass dieselbe durch scheinbare Unregelmäßigkeiten (wie die Verwendung der ♯ und ♭ in der Notenschrift) nicht gestört wird.
english_ogden: And if we penetrate to the essence of this pictorial nature we see that this is not disturbed by apparent irregularities (like the use of ♯ and ♭ in the score).
english_pears: And if we penetrate to the essence of this pictorial character, we see that it is not impaired by apparent irregularities (such as the use of ♯ and ♭ in musical notation).

text: 4.014 A gramophone record, the musical idea, the written notes, and the sound-waves, all stand to one another in the same internal relation of depicting that holds between language and the world.
german: Die Grammophonplatte, der musikalische Gedanke, die Notenschrift, die Schallwellen, stehen alle in jener abbildenden internen Beziehung zu einander, die zwischen Sprache und Welt besteht.
english_ogden: The gramophone record, the musical thought, the score, the waves of sound, all stand to one another in that pictorial internal relation, which holds between language and the world.
english_pears: A gramophone record, the musical idea, the written notes, and the sound-waves, all stand to one another in the same internal relation of depicting that holds between language and the world.

text: 4.0141 There is a general rule by means of which the musician can obtain the symphony from the score, and which makes it possible to derive the symphony from the groove on the gramophone record, and, using the first rule, to derive the score again. That is what constitutes the inner similarity between these things which seem to be constructed in such entirely different ways. And that rule is the law of projection which projects the symphony into the language of musical notation. It is the rule for translating this language into the language of gramophone records.
german: Dass es eine allgemeine Regel gibt, durch die der Musiker aus der Partitur die Symphonie entnehmen kann, durch welche man aus der Linie auf der Grammophonplatte die Symphonie und nach der ersten Regel wieder die Partitur ableiten kann, darin besteht eben die innere Ähnlichkeit dieser scheinbar so ganz verschiedenen Gebilde. Und jene Regel ist das Gesetz der Projektion, welches die Symphonie in die Notensprache projiziert. Sie ist die Regel der Übersetzung der Notensprache in die Sprache der Grammophonplatte.
english_ogden: In the fact that there is a general rule by which the musician is able to read the symphony out of the score, and that there is a rule by which one could reconstruct the symphony from the line on a gramophone record and from this again—by means of the first rule—construct the score, herein lies the internal similarity between these things which at first sight seem to be entirely different. And the rule is the law of projection which projects the symphony into the language of the musical score. It is the rule of translation of this language into the language of the gramophone record.
english_pears: There is a general rule by means of which the musician can obtain the symphony from the score, and which makes it possible to derive the symphony from the groove on the gramophone record, and, using the first rule, to derive the score again. That is what constitutes the inner similarity between these things which seem to be constructed in such entirely different ways. And that rule is the law of projection which projects the symphony into the language of musical notation. It is the rule for translating this language into the language of gramophone records.

text: 4.015 The possibility of all imagery, of all our pictorial modes of expression, is contained in the logic of depiction.
german: Die Möglichkeit aller Gleichnisse, der ganzen Bildhaftigkeit unserer Ausdrucksweise, ruht in der Logik der Abbildung.
english_ogden: The possibility of all similes, of all the images of our language, rests on the logic of representation.
english_pears: The possibility of all imagery, of all our pictorial modes of expression, is contained in the logic of depiction.

text: 4.016 In order to understand the essential nature of a proposition, we should consider hieroglyphic script, which depicts the facts that it describes.
german: Um das Wesen des Satzes zu verstehen, denken wir an die Hieroglyphenschrift, welche die Tatsachen die sie beschreibt abbildet.
english_ogden: In order to understand the essence of the proposition, consider hieroglyphic writing, which pictures the facts it describes.
english_pears: In order to understand the essential nature of a proposition, we should consider hieroglyphic script, which depicts the facts that it describes.

text: 4.02 We can see this from the fact that we understand the sense of a propositional sign without its having been explained to us.
german: Dies sehen wir daraus, dass wir den Sinn des Satzzeichens verstehen, ohne dass er uns erklärt wurde.
english_ogden: This we see from the fact that we understand the sense of the propositional sign, without having had it explained to us.
english_pears: We can see this from the fact that we understand the sense of a propositional sign without its having been explained to us.

text: 4.021 A proposition is a picture of reality: for if I understand a proposition, I know the situation that it represents. And I understand the proposition without having had its sense explained to me.
german: Der Satz ist ein Bild der Wirklichkeit: Denn ich kenne die von ihm dargestellte Sachlage, wenn ich den Satz verstehe. Und den Satz verstehe ich, ohne dass mir sein Sinn erklärt wurde.
english_ogden: The proposition is a picture of reality, for I know the state of affairs presented by it, if I understand the proposition. And I understand the proposition, without its sense having been explained to me.
english_pears: A proposition is a picture of reality: for if I understand a proposition, I know the situation that it represents. And I understand the proposition without having had its sense explained to me.

text: 4.022 A proposition shows its sense.
german: Der Satz zeigt seinen Sinn.
english_ogden: The proposition shows its sense.
english_pears: A proposition shows its sense.

text: 4.023 A proposition must restrict reality to two alternatives: yes or no.
german: Die Wirklichkeit muss durch den Satz auf ja oder nein fixiert sein.
english_ogden: The proposition determines reality to this extent, that one only needs to say “Yes” or “No” to it to make it agree with reality.
english_pears: A proposition must restrict reality to two alternatives: yes or no.

text: 4.024 To understand a proposition means to know what is the case if it is true.
german: Einen Satz verstehen, heißt, wissen was der Fall ist, wenn er wahr ist.
english_ogden: To understand a proposition means to know what is the case, if it is true.
english_pears: To understand a proposition means to know what is the case if it is true.

text: 4.025 When translating one language into another, we do not proceed by translating each proposition of the one into a proposition of the other, but merely by translating the constituents of propositions.
german: Die Übersetzung einer Sprache in eine andere geht nicht so vor sich, dass man jeden Satz der einen in einen Satz der anderen übersetzt, sondern nur die Satzbestandteile werden übersetzt.
english_ogden: The translation of one language into another is not a process of translating each proposition of the one into a proposition of the other, but only the constituent parts of propositions are translated.
english_pears: When translating one language into another, we do not proceed by translating each proposition of the one into a proposition of the other, but merely by translating the constituents of propositions.

text: 4.026 The meanings of simple signs (words) must be explained to us if we are to understand them.
german: Die Bedeutung der einfachen Zeichen (der Wörter) müssen uns erklärt werden, dass wir sie verstehen.
english_ogden: The meanings of the simple signs (the words) must be explained to us, if we are to understand them.
english_pears: The meanings of simple signs (words) must be explained to us if we are to understand them.

text: 4.027 It belongs to the essence of a proposition that it should be able to communicate a new sense to us.
german: Es liegt im Wesen des Satzes, dass er uns einen neuen Sinn mitteilen kann.
english_ogden: It is essential to propositions, that they can communicate a new sense to us.
english_pears: It belongs to the essence of a proposition that it should be able to communicate a new sense to us.

text: 4.03 A proposition must use old expressions to communicate a new sense.
german: Ein Satz muss mit alten Ausdrücken einen neuen Sinn mitteilen.
english_ogden: A proposition must communicate a new sense with old words.
english_pears: A proposition must use old expressions to communicate a new sense.

text: 4.031 In a proposition a situation is, as it were, constructed by way of experiment.
german: Im Satz wird gleichsam eine Sachlage probeweise zusammengestellt.
english_ogden: In the proposition a state of affairs is, as it were, put together for the sake of experiment.
english_pears: In a proposition a situation is, as it were, constructed by way of experiment.

text: 4.0311 One name stands for one thing, another for another thing, and they are combined with one another. In this way the whole group—like a tableau vivant—presents a state of affairs.
german: Ein Name steht für ein Ding, ein anderer für ein anderes Ding und untereinander sind sie verbunden, so stellt das Ganze – wie ein lebendes Bild – den Sachverhalt vor.
english_ogden: One name stands for one thing, and another for another thing, and they are connected together. And so the whole, like a living picture, presents the atomic fact.
english_pears: One name stands for one thing, another for another thing, and they are combined with one another. In this way the whole group—like a tableau vivant—presents a state of affairs.

text: 4.0312 The possibility of propositions is based on the principle that objects have signs as their representatives.
german: Die Möglichkeit des Satzes beruht auf dem Prinzip der Vertretung von Gegenständen durch Zeichen.
english_ogden: The possibility of propositions is based upon the principle of the representation of objects by signs.
english_pears: The possibility of propositions is based on the principle that objects have signs as their representatives.

text: 4.032 It is only in so far as a proposition is logically articulated that it is a picture of a situation.
german: Nur insoweit ist der Satz ein Bild der Sachlage, als er logisch gegliedert ist.
english_ogden: The proposition is a picture of its state of affairs, only in so far as it is logically articulated.
english_pears: It is only in so far as a proposition is logically articulated that it is a picture of a situation.

text: 4.04 In a proposition there must be exactly as many distinguishable parts as in the situation that it represents.
german: Am Satz muss gerade soviel zu unterscheiden sein, als an der Sachlage, die er darstellt.
english_ogden: In the proposition there must be exactly as many things distinguishable as there are in the state of affairs, which it represents.
english_pears: In a proposition there must be exactly as many distinguishable parts as in the situation that it represents.

text: 4.041 This mathematical multiplicity, of course, cannot itself be the subject of depiction. One cannot get away from it when depicting.
german: Diese mathematische Mannigfaltigkeit kann man natürlich nicht selbst wieder abbilden. Aus ihr kann man beim Abbilden nicht heraus.
english_ogden: This mathematical multiplicity naturally cannot in its turn be represented. One cannot get outside it in the representation.
english_pears: This mathematical multiplicity, of course, cannot itself be the subject of depiction. One cannot get away from it when depicting.

text: 4.0411 If, for example, we wanted to express what we now write as ‘(x).fx’ by putting an affix in front of ‘fx’—for instance by writing ‘Gen. fx’—it would not be adequate: we should not know what was being generalized. If we wanted to signalize it with an affix ‘g’—for instance by writing ‘f(xg)’—that would not be adequate either: we should not know the scope of the generality-sign.
german: Wollten wir z. B. das, was wir durch „(x).fx“ ausdrücken, durch Vorsetzen eines Indexes vor „fx“ ausdrücken – etwa so: „Alg.fx“ – es würde nicht genügen – wir wüssten nicht, was verallgemeinert wurde. Wollten wir es durch einen Index „a“ anzeigen – etwa so: „f(xa)“ – es würde auch nicht genügen – wir wüssten nicht den Bereich der Allgemeinheitsbezeichnung.
english_ogden: If we tried, for example, to express what is expressed by “(x).fx” by putting an index before fx, like: “Gen. fx”, it would not do, we should not know what was generalized. If we tried to show it by an index g, like: “f(xg)” it would not do—we should not know the scope of the generalization.
english_pears: If, for example, we wanted to express what we now write as ‘(x).fx’ by putting an affix in front of ‘fx’—for instance by writing ‘Gen. fx’—it would not be adequate: we should not know what was being generalized. If we wanted to signalize it with an affix ‘g’—for instance by writing ‘f(xg)’—that would not be adequate either: we should not know the scope of the generality-sign.

text: 4.0412 For the same reason the idealist’s appeal to ‘spatial spectacles’ is inadequate to explain the seeing of spatial relations, because it cannot explain the multiplicity of these relations.
german: Aus demselben Grunde genügt die idealistische Erklärung des Sehens der räumlichen Beziehungen durch die „Raumbrille“ nicht, weil sie nicht die Mannigfaltigkeit dieser Beziehungen erklären kann.
english_ogden: For the same reason the idealist explanation of the seeing of spatial relations through “spatial spectacles” does not do, because it cannot explain the multiplicity of these relations.
english_pears: For the same reason the idealist’s appeal to ‘spatial spectacles’ is inadequate to explain the seeing of spatial relations, because it cannot explain the multiplicity of these relations.

text: 4.05 Reality is compared with propositions.
german: Die Wirklichkeit wird mit dem Satz verglichen.
english_ogden: Reality is compared with the proposition.
english_pears: Reality is compared with propositions.

text: 4.06 A proposition can be true or false only in virtue of being a picture of reality.
german: Nur dadurch kann der Satz wahr oder falsch sein, indem er ein Bild der Wirklichkeit ist.
english_ogden: Propositions can be true or false only by being pictures of the reality.
english_pears: A proposition can be true or false only in virtue of being a picture of reality.

text: 4.061 It must not be overlooked that a proposition has a sense that is independent of the facts: otherwise one can easily suppose that true and false are relations of equal status between signs and what they signify.
german: Beachtet man nicht, dass der Satz einen von den Tatsachen unabhängigen Sinn hat, so kann man leicht glauben, dass wahr und falsch gleichberechtigte Beziehungen von Zeichen und Bezeichnetem sind.
english_ogden: If one does not observe that propositions have a sense independent of the facts, one can easily believe that true and false are two relations between signs and things signified with equal rights.
english_pears: It must not be overlooked that a proposition has a sense that is independent of the facts: otherwise one can easily suppose that true and false are relations of equal status between signs and what they signify.

text: 4.062 Can we not make ourselves understood with false propositions just as we have done up till now with true ones?—So long as it is known that they are meant to be false.—No! For a proposition is true if we use it to say that things stand in a certain way, and they do; and if by ‘p’ we mean ~p and things stand as we mean that they do, then, construed in the new way, ‘p’ is true and not false.
german: Kann man sich nicht mit falschen Sätzen, wie bisher mit wahren, verständigen? Solange man nur weiß, dass sie falsch gemeint sind. Nein! Denn, wahr ist ein Satz, wenn es sich so verhält, wie wir es durch ihn sagen; und wenn wir mit „p“ ~p meinen, und es sich so verhält wie wir es meinen, so ist „p“ in der neuen Auffassung wahr und nicht falsch.
english_ogden: Can we not make ourselves understood by means of false propositions as hitherto with true ones, so long as we know that they are meant to be false? No! For a proposition is true, if what we assert by means of it is the case; and if by “p” we mean ~p, and what we mean is the case, then “p” in the new conception is true and not false.
english_pears: Can we not make ourselves understood with false propositions just as we have done up till now with true ones?—So long as it is known that they are meant to be false.—No! For a proposition is true if we use it to say that things stand in a certain way, and they do; and if by ‘p’ we mean ~p and things stand as we mean that they do, then, construed in the new way, ‘p’ is true and not false.

text: 4.0621 But it is important that the signs ‘p’ and ‘~p’ can say the same thing. For it shows that nothing in reality corresponds to the sign ‘~’.
german: Dass aber die Zeichen „p“ und „~p“ das gleiche sagen können, ist wichtig. Denn es zeigt, dass dem Zeichen „~“ in der Wirklichkeit nichts entspricht.
english_ogden: That, however, the signs “p” and “~p” can say the same thing is important, for it shows that the sign “~” corresponds to nothing in reality.
english_pears: But it is important that the signs ‘p’ and ‘~p’ can say the same thing. For it shows that nothing in reality corresponds to the sign ‘~’.

text: 4.063 An analogy to illustrate the concept of truth: imagine a black spot on white paper: you can describe the shape of the spot by saying, for each point on the sheet, whether it is black or white. To the fact that a point is black there corresponds a positive fact, and to the fact that a point is white (not black), a negative fact. If I designate a point on the sheet (a truth-value according to Frege), then this corresponds to the supposition that is put forward for judgement, etc. etc.
german: Ein Bild zur Erklärung des Wahrheitsbegriffes: Schwarzer Fleck auf weißem Papier; die Form des Fleckes kann man beschreiben, indem man für jeden Punkt der Fläche angibt, ob er weiß oder schwarz ist. Der Tatsache, dass ein Punkt schwarz ist, entspricht eine positive – der, dass ein Punkt weiß (nicht schwarz) ist, eine negative Tatsache. Bezeichne ich einen Punkt der Fläche (einen Fregeschen Wahrheitswert), so entspricht dies der Annahme, die zur Beurteilung aufgestellt wird, etc. etc.
english_ogden: An illustration to explain the concept of truth. A black spot on white paper; the form of the spot can be described by saying of each point of the plane whether it is white or black. To the fact that a point is black corresponds a positive fact; to the fact that a point is white (not black), a negative fact. If I indicate a point of the plane (a truth-value in Frege’s terminology), this corresponds to the assumption proposed for judgment, etc. etc.
english_pears: An analogy to illustrate the concept of truth: imagine a black spot on white paper: you can describe the shape of the spot by saying, for each point on the sheet, whether it is black or white. To the fact that a point is black there corresponds a positive fact, and to the fact that a point is white (not black), a negative fact. If I designate a point on the sheet (a truth-value according to Frege), then this corresponds to the supposition that is put forward for judgement, etc. etc.

text: 4.064 Every proposition must already have a sense: it cannot be given a sense by affirmation. Indeed its sense is just what is affirmed. And the same applies to negation, etc.
german: Jeder Satz muss schon einen Sinn haben; die Bejahung kann ihn ihm nicht geben, denn sie bejaht ja gerade den Sinn. Und dasselbe gilt von der Verneinung, etc.
english_ogden: Every proposition must already have a sense; assertion cannot give it a sense, for what it asserts is the sense itself. And the same holds of denial, etc.
english_pears: Every proposition must already have a sense: it cannot be given a sense by affirmation. Indeed its sense is just what is affirmed. And the same applies to negation, etc.

text: 4.0641 One could say that negation must be related to the logical place determined by the negated proposition.
german: Man könnte sagen: Die Verneinung bezieht sich schon auf den logischen Ort, den der verneinte Satz bestimmt.
english_ogden: One could say, the denial is already related to the logical place determined by the proposition that is denied.
english_pears: One could say that negation must be related to the logical place determined by the negated proposition.

text: 4.1 Propositions represent the existence and non-existence of states of affairs.
german: Der Satz stellt das Bestehen und Nichtbestehen der Sachverhalte dar.
english_ogden: A proposition presents the existence and non-existence of atomic facts.
english_pears: Propositions represent the existence and non-existence of states of affairs.

text: 4.11 The totality of true propositions is the whole of natural science (or the whole corpus of the natural sciences).
german: Die Gesamtheit der wahren Sätze ist die gesamte Naturwissenschaft (oder die Gesamtheit der Naturwissenschaften).
english_ogden: The totality of true propositions is the total natural science (or the totality of the natural sciences).
english_pears: The totality of true propositions is the whole of natural science (or the whole corpus of the natural sciences).

text: 4.111 Philosophy is not one of the natural sciences.
german: Die Philosophie ist keine der Naturwissenschaften.
english_ogden: Philosophy is not one of the natural sciences.
english_pears: Philosophy is not one of the natural sciences.

text: 4.112 Philosophy aims at the logical clarification of thoughts.
german: Der Zweck der Philosophie ist die logische Klärung der Gedanken.
english_ogden: The object of philosophy is the logical clarification of thoughts.
english_pears: Philosophy aims at the logical clarification of thoughts.

text: 4.1121 Psychology is no more closely related to philosophy than any other natural science.
german: Die Psychologie ist der Philosophie nicht verwandter als irgend eine andere Naturwissenschaft.
english_ogden: Psychology is no nearer related to philosophy, than is any other natural science.
english_pears: Psychology is no more closely related to philosophy than any other natural science.

text: 4.1122 Darwin’s theory has no more to do with philosophy than any other hypothesis in natural science.
german: Die Darwinsche Theorie hat mit der Philosophie nicht mehr zu schaffen als irgendeine andere Hypothese der Naturwissenschaft.
english_ogden: The Darwinian theory has no more to do with philosophy than has any other hypothesis of natural science.
english_pears: Darwin’s theory has no more to do with philosophy than any other hypothesis in natural science.

text: 4.113 Philosophy sets limits to the much disputed sphere of natural science.
german: Die Philosophie begrenzt das bestreitbare Gebiet der Naturwissenschaft.
english_ogden: Philosophy limits the disputable sphere of natural science.
english_pears: Philosophy sets limits to the much disputed sphere of natural science.

text: 4.114 It must set limits to what can be thought; and, in doing so, to what cannot be thought.
german: Sie soll das Denkbare abgrenzen und damit das Undenkbare.
english_ogden: It should limit the thinkable and thereby the unthinkable.
english_pears: It must set limits to what can be thought; and, in doing so, to what cannot be thought.

text: 4.115 It will signify what cannot be said, by presenting clearly what can be said.
german: Sie wird das Unsagbare bedeuten, indem sie das Sagbare klar darstellt.
english_ogden: It will mean the unspeakable by clearly displaying the speakable.
english_pears: It will signify what cannot be said, by presenting clearly what can be said.

text: 4.116 Everything that can be thought at all can be thought clearly. Everything that can be put into words can be put clearly.
german: Alles was überhaupt gedacht werden kann, kann klar gedacht werden. Alles, was sich aussprechen lässt, lässt sich klar aussprechen.
english_ogden: Everything that can be thought at all can be thought clearly. Everything that can be said can be said clearly.
english_pears: Everything that can be thought at all can be thought clearly. Everything that can be put into words can be put clearly.

text: 4.12 Propositions can represent the whole of reality, but they cannot represent what they must have in common with reality in order to be able to represent it—logical form.
german: Der Satz kann die gesamte Wirklichkeit darstellen, aber er kann nicht das darstellen, was er mit der Wirklichkeit gemein haben muss, um sie darstellen zu können – die logische Form.
english_ogden: Propositions can represent the whole reality, but they cannot represent what they must have in common with reality in order to be able to represent it—the logical form.
english_pears: Propositions can represent the whole of reality, but they cannot represent what they must have in common with reality in order to be able to represent it—logical form.

text: 4.121 Propositions cannot represent logical form: it is mirrored in them.
german: Der Satz kann die logische Form nicht darstellen, sie spiegelt sich in ihm.
english_ogden: Propositions cannot represent the logical form: this mirrors itself in the propositions.
english_pears: Propositions cannot represent logical form: it is mirrored in them.

text: 4.1211 Thus one proposition ‘fa’ shows that the object a occurs in its sense, two propositions ‘fa’ and ‘ga’ show that the same object is mentioned in both of them.
german: So zeigt ein Satz „fa“, dass in seinem Sinn der Gegenstand a vorkommt, zwei Sätze „fa“ und „ga“, dass in ihnen beiden von demselben Gegenstand die Rede ist.
english_ogden: Thus a proposition “fa” shows that in its sense the object a occurs, two propositions “fa” and “ga” that they are both about the same object.
english_pears: Thus one proposition ‘fa’ shows that the object a occurs in its sense, two propositions ‘fa’ and ‘ga’ show that the same object is mentioned in both of them.

text: 4.1212 What can be shown, cannot be said.
german: Was gezeigt werden kann, kann nicht gesagt werden.
english_ogden: What can be shown cannot be said.
english_pears: What can be shown, cannot be said.

text: 4.1213 Now, too, we understand our feeling that once we have a sign-language in which everything is all right, we already have a correct logical point of view.
german: Jetzt verstehen wir auch unser Gefühl: dass wir im Besitze einer richtigen logischen Auffassung seien, wenn nur einmal alles in unserer Zeichensprache stimmt.
english_ogden: Now we understand our feeling that we are in possession of the right logical conception, if only all is right in our symbolism.
english_pears: Now, too, we understand our feeling that once we have a sign-language in which everything is all right, we already have a correct logical point of view.

text: 4.122 In a certain sense we can talk about formal properties of objects and states of affairs, or, in the case of facts, about structural properties: and in the same sense about formal relations and structural relations.
german: Wir können in gewissem Sinne von formalen Eigenschaften der Gegenstände und Sachverhalte bezw. von Eigenschaften der Struktur der Tatsachen reden, und in demselben Sinne von formalen Relationen und Relationen von Strukturen.

text: 4.1221 An internal property of a fact can also be called a feature of that fact (in the sense in which we speak of facial features, for example).
german: Eine interne Eigenschaft einer Tatsache können wir auch einen Zug dieser Tatsache nennen. (In dem Sinn, in welchem wir etwa von Gesichtszügen sprechen.)
english_ogden: An internal property of a fact we also call a feature of this fact. (In the sense in which we speak of facial features.)
english_pears: An internal property of a fact can also be called a feature of that fact (in the sense in which we speak of facial features, for example).

text: 4.123 A property is internal if it is unthinkable that its object should not possess it.
german: Eine Eigenschaft ist intern, wenn es undenkbar ist, dass ihr Gegenstand sie nicht besitzt.
english_ogden: A property is internal if it is unthinkable that its object does not possess it.
english_pears: A property is internal if it is unthinkable that its object should not possess it.

text: 4.124 The existence of an internal property of a possible situation is not expressed by means of a proposition: rather, it expresses itself in the proposition representing the situation, by means of an internal property of that proposition.
german: Das Bestehen einer internen Eigenschaft einer möglichen Sachlage wird nicht durch einen Satz ausgedrückt, sondern es drückt sich in dem sie darstellenden Satz durch eine interne Eigenschaft dieses Satzes aus.
english_ogden: The existence of an internal property of a possible state of affairs is not expressed by a proposition, but it expresses itself in the proposition which presents that state of affairs, by an internal property of this proposition.

text: 4.1241 It is impossible to distinguish forms from one another by saying that one has this property and another that property: for this presupposes that it makes sense to ascribe either property to either form.
german: Formen kann man nicht dadurch voneinander unterscheiden, dass man sagt, die eine habe diese, die andere aber jene Eigenschaft; denn dies setzt voraus, dass es einen Sinn habe, beide Eigenschaften von beiden Formen auszusagen.

text: 4.125 The existence of an internal relation between possible situations expresses itself in language by means of an internal relation between the propositions representing them.
german: Das Bestehen einer internen Relation zwischen möglichen Sachlagen drückt sich sprachlich durch eine interne Relation zwischen den sie darstellenden Sätzen aus.
english_ogden: The existence of an internal relation between possible states of affairs expresses itself in language by an internal relation between the propositions presenting them.
english_pears: The existence of an internal relation between possible situations expresses itself in language by means of an internal relation between the propositions representing them.

text: 4.1251 Here we have the answer to the vexed question ‘whether all relations are internal or external’.
german: Hier erledigt sich nun die Streitfrage, „ob alle Relationen intern oder extern seien“.
english_ogden: Now this settles the disputed question “whether all relations are internal or external”.
english_pears: Here we have the answer to the vexed question ‘whether all relations are internal or external’.

german: Reihen, welche durch interne Relationen geordnet sind, nenne ich Formenreihen.
english_ogden: Series which are ordered by internal relations I call formal series.
english_pears: I call a series that is ordered by an internal relation a series of forms.

german: In dem Sinne, in welchem wir von formalen Eigenschaften sprechen, können wir nun auch von formalen Begriffen reden.

english_pears: The propositional variable signifies the formal concept, and its values signify the objects that fall under the concept.

english_ogden: That the truth of one proposition follows from the truth of other propositions, we perceive from the structure of the propositions.
english_pears: When the truth of one proposition follows from the truth of others, we can see this from the structure of the propositions.

text: 5.131 If the truth of one proposition follows from the truth of others, this finds expression in relations in which the forms of the propositions stand to one another: nor is it necessary for us to set up these relations between them, by combining them with one another in a single proposition; on the contrary, the relations are internal, and their existence is an immediate result of the existence of the propositions.
german: Folgt die Wahrheit eines Satzes aus der Wahrheit anderer, so drückt sich dies durch Beziehungen aus, in welchen die Formen jener Sätze zu einander stehen; und zwar brauchen wir sie nicht erst in jene Beziehungen zu setzen, indem wir sie in einem Satz miteinander verbinden, sondern diese Beziehungen sind intern und bestehen, sobald, und dadurch dass, jene Sätze bestehen.
english_ogden: If the truth of one proposition follows from the truth of others, this expresses itself in relations in which the forms of these propositions stand to one another, and we do not need to put them in these relations first by connecting them with one another in a proposition; for these relations are internal, and exist as soon as, and by the very fact that, the propositions exist.
english_pears: If the truth of one proposition follows from the truth of others, this finds expression in relations in which the forms of the propositions stand to one another: nor is it necessary for us to set up these relations between them, by combining them with one another in a single proposition; on the contrary, the relations are internal, and their existence is an immediate result of the existence of the propositions.

text: 5.1311 When we infer q from p∨q and ~p, the relation between the propositional forms of ‘p∨q’ and ‘~p’ is masked, in this case, by our mode of signifying. But if instead of ‘p∨q’ we write, for example, ‘p|q.|.p|q’, and instead of ‘~p’, ‘p|p’ (p|q = neither p nor q), then the inner connexion becomes obvious.
german: Wenn wir von p∨q und ~p auf q schließen, so ist hier durch die Bezeichnungsweise die Beziehung der Satzformen von „p∨q“ und „~p“ verhüllt. Schreiben wir aber z. B. statt „p∨q“ „p|q.|.p|q“ und statt „~p“ „p|p“ (p|q = weder p, noch q), so wird der innere Zusammenhang offenbar.
english_ogden: When we conclude from p∨q and ~p to q the relation between the forms of the propositions “p∨q” and “~p” is here concealed by the method of symbolizing. But if we write, e.g. instead of “p∨q” “p|q.|.p|q” and instead of “~p” “p|p” (p|q = neither p nor q), then the inner connexion becomes obvious.
english_pears: When we infer q from p∨q and ~p, the relation between the propositional forms of ‘p∨q’ and ‘~p’ is masked, in this case, by our mode of signifying. But if instead of ‘p∨q’ we write, for example, ‘p|q.|.p|q’, and instead of ‘~p’, ‘p|p’ (p|q = neither p nor q), then the inner connexion becomes obvious.

text: 5.132 If p follows from q, I can make an inference from q to p, deduce p from q.
german: Folgt p aus q, so kann ich von q auf p schließen; p aus q folgern.
english_ogden: If p follows from q, I can conclude from q to p; infer p from q.
english_pears: If p follows from q, I can make an inference from q to p, deduce p from q.

text: 5.133 All deductions are made a priori.
german: Alles Folgern geschieht a priori.
english_ogden: All inference takes place a priori.
english_pears: All deductions are made a priori.

text: 5.134 One elementary proposition cannot be deduced from another.
german: Aus einem Elementarsatz lässt sich kein anderer folgern.
english_ogden: From an elementary proposition no other can be inferred.
english_pears: One elementary proposition cannot be deduced from another.

text: 5.135 There is no possible way of making an inference from the existence of one situation to the existence of another, entirely different situation.
german: Auf keine Weise kann aus dem Bestehen irgend einer Sachlage auf das Bestehen einer von ihr gänzlich verschiedenen Sachlage geschlossen werden.
english_ogden: In no way can an inference be made from the existence of one state of affairs to the existence of another entirely different from it.
english_pears: There is no possible way of making an inference from the existence of one situation to the existence of another, entirely different situation.

text: 5.136 There is no causal nexus to justify such an inference.
german: Einen Kausalnexus, der einen solchen Schluss rechtfertigte, gibt es nicht.
english_ogden: There is no causal nexus which justifies such an inference.
english_pears: There is no causal nexus to justify such an inference.

text: 5.1361 We cannot infer the events of the future from those of the present.
german: Die Ereignisse der Zukunft können wir nicht aus den gegenwärtigen erschließen.
english_ogden: The events of the future cannot be inferred from those of the present.
english_pears: We cannot infer the events of the future from those of the present.

text: 5.1362 The freedom of the will consists in the impossibility of knowing actions that still lie in the future. We could know them only if causality were an inner necessity like that of logical inference.—The connexion between knowledge and what is known is that of logical necessity.
german: Die Willensfreiheit besteht darin, dass zukünftige Handlungen jetzt nicht gewusst werden können. Nur dann könnten wir sie wissen, wenn die Kausalität eine innere Notwendigkeit wäre, wie die des logischen Schlusses. – Der Zusammenhang von Wissen und Gewusstem ist der der logischen Notwendigkeit.
english_ogden: The freedom of the will consists in the fact that future actions cannot be known now. We could only know them if causality were an inner necessity, like that of logical deduction.—The connexion of knowledge and what is known is that of logical necessity.
english_pears: The freedom of the will consists in the impossibility of knowing actions that still lie in the future. We could know them only if causality were an inner necessity like that of logical inference.—The connexion between knowledge and what is known is that of logical necessity.

text: 5.1363 If the truth of a proposition does not follow from the fact that it is self-evident to us, then its self-evidence in no way justifies our belief in its truth.
german: Wenn daraus, dass ein Satz uns einleuchtet, nicht folgt, dass er wahr ist, so ist das Einleuchten auch keine Rechtfertigung für unseren Glauben an seine Wahrheit.
english_ogden: If from the fact that a proposition is obvious to us it does not follow that it is true, then obviousness is no justification for our belief in its truth.
english_pears: If the truth of a proposition does not follow from the fact that it is self-evident to us, then its self-evidence in no way justifies our belief in its truth.

text: 5.14 If one proposition follows from another, then the latter says more than the former, and the former less than the latter.
german: Folgt ein Satz aus einem anderen, so sagt dieser mehr als jener, jener weniger als dieser.
english_ogden: If a proposition follows from another, then the latter says more than the former, the former less than the latter.
english_pears: If one proposition follows from another, then the latter says more than the former, and the former less than the latter.

text: 5.141 If p follows from q and q from p, then they are one and the same proposition.
german: Folgt p aus q und q aus p, so sind sie ein und derselbe Satz.
english_ogden: If p follows from q and q from p then they are one and the same proposition.
english_pears: If p follows from q and q from p, then they are one and the same proposition.

text: 5.142 A tautology follows from all propositions: it says nothing.
german: Die Tautologie folgt aus allen Sätzen: sie sagt nichts.
english_ogden: A tautology follows from all propositions: it says nothing.
english_pears: A tautology follows from all propositions: it says nothing.

text: 5.143 Contradiction is that common factor of propositions which no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is the common factor of all propositions that have nothing in common with one another.
german: Die Kontradiktion ist das Gemeinsame der Sätze, was kein Satz mit einem anderen gemein hat. Die Tautologie ist das Gemeinsame aller Sätze, welche nichts miteinander gemein haben.
english_ogden: Contradiction is something shared by propositions, which no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is that which is shared by all propositions, which have nothing in common with one another.
english_pears: Contradiction is that common factor of propositions which no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is the common factor of all propositions that have nothing in common with one another.

text: 5.15 If Tr is the number of the truth-grounds of a proposition ‘r’, and if Trs is the number of the truth-grounds of a proposition ‘s’ that are at the same time truth-grounds of ‘r’, then we call the ratio Trs : Tr the degree of probability that the proposition ‘r’ gives to the proposition ‘s’.
german: Ist Wr die Anzahl der Wahrheitsgründe des Satzes „r“, Wrs die Anzahl derjenigen Wahrheitsgründe des Satzes „s“, die zugleich Wahrheitsgründe von „r“ sind, dann nennen wir das Verhältnis: Wrs : Wr das Maß der Wahrscheinlichkeit, welche der Satz „r“ dem Satz „s“ gibt.
english_ogden: If Tr is the number of the truth-grounds of the proposition “r”, Trs the number of those truth-grounds of the proposition “s” which are at the same time truth-grounds of “r”, then we call the ratio Trs : Tr the measure of the probability which the proposition “r” gives to the proposition “s”.
english_pears: If Tr is the number of the truth-grounds of a proposition ‘r’, and if Trs is the number of the truth-grounds of a proposition ‘s’ that are at the same time truth-grounds of ‘r’, then we call the ratio Trs : Tr the degree of probability that the proposition ‘r’ gives to the proposition ‘s’.

text: 5.151 In a schema like the one above in 5.101, let Tr be the number of ‘T’s’ in the proposition r, and let Trs, be the number of ‘T’s’ in the proposition s that stand in columns in which the proposition r has ‘T’s’. Then the proposition r gives to the proposition s the probability Trs : Tr.
german: Sei in einem Schema wie dem obigen in No. 5.101 Wr die Anzahl der „W“ im Satze r; Wrs die Anzahl derjenigen „W“ im Satze s, die in gleichen Kolonnen mit „W“ des Satzes r stehen. Der Satz r gibt dann dem Satze s die Wahrscheinlichkeit: Wrs : Wr.
english_ogden: Suppose in a schema like that above in No. 5.101 Tr is the number of the “T” ’s in the proposition r, Trs the number of those “T” ’s in the proposition s, which stand in the same columns as “T” ’s of the proposition r; then the proposition r gives to the proposition s the probability Trs : Tr.
english_pears: In a schema like the one above in 5.101, let Tr be the number of ‘T’s’ in the proposition r, and let Trs, be the number of ‘T’s’ in the proposition s that stand in columns in which the proposition r has ‘T’s’. Then the proposition r gives to the proposition s the probability Trs : Tr.

text: 5.1511 There is no special object peculiar to probability propositions.
german: Es gibt keinen besonderen Gegenstand, der den Wahrscheinlichkeitssätzen eigen wäre.
english_ogden: There is no special object peculiar to probability propositions.
english_pears: There is no special object peculiar to probability propositions.

text: 5.152 When propositions have no truth-arguments in common with one another, we call them independent of one another.
german: Sätze, welche keine Wahrheitsargumente mit einander gemein haben, nennen wir von einander unabhängig.
english_ogden: Propositions which have no truth-arguments in common with one another we call independent.
english_pears: When propositions have no truth-arguments in common with one another, we call them independent of one another.

text: 5.153 In itself, a proposition is neither probable nor improbable. Either an event occurs or it does not: there is no middle way.
german: Ein Satz ist an sich weder wahrscheinlich noch unwahrscheinlich. Ein Ereignis trifft ein, oder es trifft nicht ein, ein Mittelding gibt es nicht.
english_ogden: A proposition is in itself neither probable nor improbable. An event occurs or does not occur, there is no middle course.
english_pears: In itself, a proposition is neither probable nor improbable. Either an event occurs or it does not: there is no middle way.

text: 5.154 Suppose that an urn contains black and white balls in equal numbers (and none of any other kind). I draw one ball after another, putting them back into the urn. By this experiment I can establish that the number of black balls drawn and the number of white balls drawn approximate to one another as the draw continues.
german: In einer Urne seien gleichviel weiße und schwarze Kugeln (und keine anderen). Ich ziehe eine Kugel nach der anderen und lege sie wieder in die Urne zurück. Dann kann ich durch den Versuch feststellen, dass sich die Zahlen der gezogenen schwarzen und weißen Kugeln bei fortgesetztem Ziehen einander nähern.
english_ogden: In an urn there are equal numbers of white and black balls (and no others). I draw one ball after another and put them back in the urn. Then I can determine by the experiment that the numbers of the black and white balls which are drawn approximate as the drawing continues.
english_pears: Suppose that an urn contains black and white balls in equal numbers (and none of any other kind). I draw one ball after another, putting them back into the urn. By this experiment I can establish that the number of black balls drawn and the number of white balls drawn approximate to one another as the draw continues.

text: 5.155 The minimal unit for a probability proposition is this: The circumstances—of which I have no further knowledge—give such and such a degree of probability to the occurrence of a particular event.
german: Die Einheit des Wahrscheinlichkeitssatzes ist: Die Umstände – die ich sonst nicht weiter kenne – geben dem Eintreffen eines bestimmten Ereignisses den und den Grad der Wahrscheinlichkeit.
english_ogden: The unit of the probability proposition is: The circumstances—with which I am not further acquainted—give to the occurrence of a definite event such and such a degree of probability.
english_pears: The minimal unit for a probability proposition is this: The circumstances—of which I have no further knowledge—give such and such a degree of probability to the occurrence of a particular event.

text: 5.156 It is in this way that probability is a generalization.
german: So ist die Wahrscheinlichkeit eine Verallgemeinerung.
english_ogden: Probability is a generalization.
english_pears: It is in this way that probability is a generalization.

text: 5.2 The structures of propositions stand in internal relations to one another.
german: Die Strukturen der Sätze stehen in internen Beziehungen zu einander.
english_ogden: The structures of propositions stand to one another in internal relations.
english_pears: The structures of propositions stand in internal relations to one another.

text: 5.21 In order to give prominence to these internal relations we can adopt the following mode of expression: we can represent a proposition as the result of an operation that produces it out of other propositions (which are the bases of the operation).
german: Wir können diese internen Beziehungen dadurch in unserer Ausdrucksweise hervorheben, dass wir einen Satz als Resultat einer Operation darstellen, die ihn aus anderen Sätzen (den Basen der Operation) hervorbringt.
english_ogden: We can bring out these internal relations in our manner of expression, by presenting a proposition as the result of an operation which produces it from other propositions (the bases of the operation).
english_pears: In order to give prominence to these internal relations we can adopt the following mode of expression: we can represent a proposition as the result of an operation that produces it out of other propositions (which are the bases of the operation).

text: 5.22 An operation is the expression of a relation between the structures of its result and of its bases.
german: Die Operation ist der Ausdruck einer Beziehung zwischen den Strukturen ihres Resultats und ihrer Basen.
english_ogden: The operation is the expression of a relation between the structures of its result and its bases.
english_pears: An operation is the expression of a relation between the structures of its result and of its bases.

text: 5.23 The operation is what has to be done to the one proposition in order to make the other out of it.
german: Die Operation ist das, was mit dem einen Satz geschehen muss, um aus ihm den anderen zu machen.
english_ogden: The operation is that which must happen to a proposition in order to make another out of it.
english_pears: The operation is what has to be done to the one proposition in order to make the other out of it.

text: 5.231 And that will, of course, depend on their formal properties, on the internal similarity of their forms.
german: Und das wird natürlich von ihren formalen Eigenschaften, von der internen Ähnlichkeit ihrer Formen abhängen.
english_ogden: And that will naturally depend on their formal properties, on the internal similarity of their forms.
english_pears: And that will, of course, depend on their formal properties, on the internal similarity of their forms.

text: 5.232 The internal relation by which a series is ordered is equivalent to the operation that produces one term from another.
german: Die interne Relation, die eine Reihe ordnet, ist äquivalent mit der Operation, durch welche ein Glied aus dem anderen entsteht.
english_ogden: The internal relation which orders a series is equivalent to the operation by which one term arises from another.
english_pears: The internal relation by which a series is ordered is equivalent to the operation that produces one term from another.

text: 5.233 Operations cannot make their appearance before the point at which one proposition is generated out of another in a logically meaningful way; i.e. the point at which the logical construction of propositions begins.
german: Die Operation kann erst dort auftreten, wo ein Satz auf logisch bedeutungsvolle Weise aus einem anderen entsteht. Also dort, wo die logische Konstruktion des Satzes anfängt.
english_ogden: The first place in which an operation can occur is where a proposition arises from another in a logically significant way; i.e. where the logical construction of the proposition begins.
english_pears: Operations cannot make their appearance before the point at which one proposition is generated out of another in a logically meaningful way; i.e. the point at which the logical construction of propositions begins.

text: 5.234 Truth-functions of elementary propositions are results of operations with elementary propositions as bases. (These operations I call truth-operations.)
german: Die Wahrheitsfunktionen der Elementarsätze sind Resultate von Operationen, die die Elementarsätze als Basen haben. (Ich nenne diese Operationen Wahrheitsoperationen.)
english_ogden: The truth-functions of elementary proposition, are results of operations which have the elementary propositions as bases. (I call these operations, truth-operations.)
english_pears: Truth-functions of elementary propositions are results of operations with elementary propositions as bases. (These operations I call truth-operations.)

text: 5.2341 The sense of a truth-function of p is a function of the sense of p.
german: Der Sinn einer Wahrheitsfunktion von p ist eine Funktion des Sinnes von p.
english_ogden: The sense of a truth-function of p is a function of the sense of p.
english_pears: The sense of a truth-function of p is a function of the sense of p.

text: 5.24 An operation manifests itself in a variable; it shows how we can get from one form of proposition to another.
german: Die Operation zeigt sich in einer Variablen; sie zeigt, wie man von einer Form von Sätzen zu einer anderen gelangen kann.
english_ogden: An operation shows itself in a variable; it shows how we can proceed from one form of proposition to another.
english_pears: An operation manifests itself in a variable; it shows how we can get from one form of proposition to another.

text: 5.241 An operation is not the mark of a form, but only of a difference between forms.
german: Die Operation kennzeichnet keine Form, sondern nur den Unterschied der Formen.
english_ogden: The operation does not characterize a form but only the difference between forms.
english_pears: An operation is not the mark of a form, but only of a difference between forms.

text: 5.242 The operation that produces ‘q’ from ‘p’ also produces ‘r’ from ‘q’, and so on. There is only one way of expressing this: ‘p’, ‘q’, ‘r’, etc. have to be variables that give expression in a general way to certain formal relations.
german: Dieselbe Operation, die „q“ aus „p“ macht, macht aus „q“ „r“ u. s. f. Dies kann nur darin ausgedrückt sein, dass „p“, „q“, „r“, etc. Variable sind, die gewisse formale Relationen allgemein zum Ausdruck bringen.
english_ogden: The same operation which makes “q” from “p”, makes “r” from “q”, and so on. This can only be expressed by the fact that “p”, “q”, “r”, etc., are variables which give general expression to certain formal relations.
english_pears: The operation that produces ‘q’ from ‘p’ also produces ‘r’ from ‘q’, and so on. There is only one way of expressing this: ‘p’, ‘q’, ‘r’, etc. have to be variables that give expression in a general way to certain formal relations.

text: 5.25 The occurrence of an operation does not characterize the sense of a proposition.
german: Das Vorkommen der Operation charakterisiert den Sinn des Satzes nicht.
english_ogden: The occurrence of an operation does not characterize the sense of a proposition.
english_pears: The occurrence of an operation does not characterize the sense of a proposition.

text: 5.251 A function cannot be its own argument, whereas an operation can take one of its own results as its base.
german: Eine Funktion kann nicht ihr eigenes Argument sein, wohl aber kann das Resultat einer Operation ihre eigene Basis werden.
english_ogden: A function cannot be its own argument, but the result of an operation can be its own basis.
english_pears: A function cannot be its own argument, whereas an operation can take one of its own results as its base.

text: 5.252 It is only in this way that the step from one term of a series of forms to another is possible (from one type to another in the hierarchies of Russell and Whitehead). (Russell and Whitehead did not admit the possibility of such steps, but repeatedly availed themselves of it.)
german: Nur so ist das Fortschreiten von Glied zu Glied in einer Formenreihe (von Type zu Type in den Hierarchien Russells und Whiteheads) möglich. (Russell und Whitehead haben die Möglichkeit dieses Fortschreitens nicht zugegeben, aber immer wieder von ihr Gebrauch gemacht.)
english_ogden: Only in this way is the progress from term to term in a formal series possible (from type to type in the hierarchy of Russell and Whitehead). (Russell and Whitehead have not admitted the possibility of this progress but have made use of it all the same.)
english_pears: It is only in this way that the step from one term of a series of forms to another is possible (from one type to another in the hierarchies of Russell and Whitehead). (Russell and Whitehead did not admit the possibility of such steps, but repeatedly availed themselves of it.)

text: 5.2521 If an operation is applied repeatedly to its own results, I speak of successive applications of it. (‘O’O’O’a’ is the result of three successive applications of the operation ‘O’ξ’ to ‘a’.)
german: Die fortgesetzte Anwendung einer Operation auf ihr eigenes Resultat nenne ich ihre successive Anwendung („O’O’O’a“ ist das Resultat der dreimaligen successiven Anwendung von „O’ξ“ auf „a“).
english_ogden: The repeated application of an operation to its own result I call its successive application (“O’O’O’a” is the result of the threefold successive application of “O’ξ” to “a”).
english_pears: If an operation is applied repeatedly to its own results, I speak of successive applications of it. (‘O’O’O’a’ is the result of three successive applications of the operation ‘O’ξ’ to ‘a’.)

text: 5.2522 Accordingly I use the sign ‘[a, x, O’x]’ for the general term of the series of forms a, O’a, O’O’a,…. This bracketed expression is a variable: the first term of the bracketed expression is the beginning of the series of forms, the second is the form of a term x arbitrarily selected from the series, and the third is the form of the term that immediately follows x in the series.
german: Das allgemeine Glied einer Formenreihe a, O’a, O’O’a,… schreibe ich daher so: „[a, x, O’x]“. Dieser Klammerausdruck ist eine Variable. Das erste Glied des Klammerausdruckes ist der Anfang der Formenreihe, das zweite die Form eines beliebigen Gliedes x der Reihe und das dritte die Form desjenigen Gliedes der Reihe, welches auf x unmittelbar folgt.
english_ogden: The general term of the formal series a, O’a, O’O’a,…. I write thus: “[a, x, O’x]”. This expression in brackets is a variable. The first term of the expression is the beginning of the formal series, the second the form of an arbitrary term x of the series, and the third the form of that term of the series which immediately follows x.
english_pears: Accordingly I use the sign ‘[a, x, O’x]’ for the general term of the series of forms a, O’a, O’O’a,…. This bracketed expression is a variable: the first term of the bracketed expression is the beginning of the series of forms, the second is the form of a term x arbitrarily selected from the series, and the third is the form of the term that immediately follows x in the series.

text: 5.2523 The concept of successive applications of an operation is equivalent to the concept ‘and so on’.
german: Der Begriff der successiven Anwendung der Operation ist äquivalent mit dem Begriff „und so weiter“.
english_ogden: The concept of the successive application of an operation is equivalent to the concept “and so on”.
english_pears: The concept of successive applications of an operation is equivalent to the concept ‘and so on’.

text: 5.253 One operation can counteract the effect of another. Operations can cancel one another.
german: Eine Operation kann die Wirkung einer anderen rückgängig machen. Operationen können einander aufheben.
english_ogden: One operation can reverse the effect of another. Operations can cancel one another.
english_pears: One operation can counteract the effect of another. Operations can cancel one another.

text: 5.254 An operation can vanish (e.g. negation in ‘~~p’: ~~p=p).
german: Die Operation kann verschwinden (z. B. die Verneinung in „~~p“: ~~p=p).
english_ogden: Operations can vanish (e.g. denial in “~~p”. ~~p=p).
english_pears: An operation can vanish (e.g. negation in ‘~~p’: ~~p=p).

text: 5.3 All propositions are results of truth-operations on elementary propositions.
german: Alle Sätze sind Resultate von Wahrheitsoperationen mit den Elementarsätzen.
english_ogden: All propositions are results of truth-operations on the elementary propositions.
english_pears: All propositions are results of truth-operations on elementary propositions.

text: 5.31 The schemata in 4.31 have a meaning even when ‘p’, ‘q’, ‘r’, etc. are not elementary propositions.
german: Die Schemata No. 4.31 haben auch dann eine Bedeutung, wenn „p“, „q“, „r“, etc. nicht Elementarsätze sind.
english_ogden: The Schemata No. 4.31 are also significant, if “p”, “q”, “r”, etc. are not elementary propositions.
english_pears: The schemata in 4.31 have a meaning even when ‘p’, ‘q’, ‘r’, etc. are not elementary propositions.

text: 5.32 All truth-functions are results of successive applications to elementary propositions of a finite number of truth-operations.
german: Alle Wahrheitsfunktionen sind Resultate der successiven Anwendung einer endlichen Anzahl von Wahrheitsoperationen auf die Elementarsätze.
english_ogden: All truth-functions are results of the successive application of a finite number of truth-operations to elementary propositions.
english_pears: All truth-functions are results of successive applications to elementary propositions of a finite number of truth-operations.

text: 5.4 At this point it becomes manifest that there are no ‘logical objects’ or ‘logical constants’ (in Frege’s and Russell’s sense).
german: Hier zeigt es sich, dass es „logische Gegenstände“, „logische Konstante“ (im Sinne Freges und Russells) nicht gibt.
english_ogden: Here it becomes clear that there are no such things as “logical objects” or “logical constants” (in the sense of Frege and Russell).
english_pears: At this point it becomes manifest that there are no ‘logical objects’ or ‘logical constants’ (in Frege’s and Russell’s sense).

text: 5.41 The reason is that the results of truth-operations on truth-functions are always identical whenever they are one and the same truth-function of elementary propositions.
german: Denn: Alle Resultate von Wahrheitsoperationen mit Wahrheitsfunktionen sind identisch, welche eine und dieselbe Wahrheitsfunktion von Elementarsätzen sind.
english_ogden: For all those results of truth-operations on truth-functions are identical, which are one and the same truth-function of elementary propositions.
english_pears: The reason is that the results of truth-operations on truth-functions are always identical whenever they are one and the same truth-function of elementary propositions.

text: 5.42 It is self-evident that ∨, ⊃, etc. are not relations in the sense in which right and left etc. are relations.
german: Dass ∨, ⊃, etc. nicht Beziehungen im Sinne von rechts und links etc. sind, leuchtet ein.
english_ogden: That ∨, ⊃, etc., are not relations in the sense of right and left, etc., is obvious.
english_pears: It is self-evident that ∨, ⊃, etc. are not relations in the sense in which right and left etc. are relations.

text: 5.43 Even at first sight it seems scarcely credible that there should follow from one fact p infinitely many others, namely ~~p, ~~~~p, etc. And it is no less remarkable that the infinite number of propositions of logic (mathematics) follow from half a dozen ‘primitive propositions’.
german: Dass aus einer Tatsache p unendlich viele andere folgen sollten, nämlich ~~p, ~~~~p, etc., ist doch von vornherein kaum zu glauben. Und nicht weniger merkwürdig ist, dass die unendliche Anzahl der Sätze der Logik (der Mathematik) aus einem halben Dutzend „Grundgesetzen“ folgen.
english_ogden: That from a fact p an infinite number of others should follow, namely, ~~p, ~~~~p, etc., is indeed hardly to be believed, and it is no less wonderful that the infinite number of propositions of logic (of mathematics) should follow from half a dozen “primitive propositions”.
english_pears: Even at first sight it seems scarcely credible that there should follow from one fact p infinitely many others, namely ~~p, ~~~~p, etc. And it is no less remarkable that the infinite number of propositions of logic (mathematics) follow from half a dozen ‘primitive propositions’.

text: 5.44 Truth-functions are not material functions.
german: Die Wahrheitsfunktionen sind keine materiellen Funktionen.
english_ogden: Truth-functions are not material functions.
english_pears: Truth-functions are not material functions.

text: 5.441 This vanishing of the apparent logical constants also occurs in the case of ‘~(∃x).~fx’, which says the same as ‘(x).fx’, and in the case of ‘(∃x).fx.x=a’, which says the same as ‘fa’.
german: Dieses Verschwinden der scheinbaren logischen Konstanten tritt auch ein, wenn „~(∃x).~fx“ dasselbe sagt wie „(x).fx“, oder „(∃x).fx.x=a“ dasselbe wie „fa“.
english_ogden: This disappearance of the apparent logical constants also occurs if “~(∃x).~fx” says the same as “(x).fx”, or “(∃x).fx.x=a” the same as “fa”.
english_pears: This vanishing of the apparent logical constants also occurs in the case of ‘~(∃x).~fx’, which says the same as ‘(x).fx’, and in the case of ‘(∃x).fx.x=a’, which says the same as ‘fa’.

text: 5.442 If we are given a proposition, then with it we are also given the results of all truth-operations that have it as their base.
german: Wenn uns ein Satz gegeben ist, so sind mit ihm auch schon die Resultate aller Wahrheitsoperationen, die ihn zur Basis haben, gegeben.
english_ogden: If a proposition is given to us then the results of all truth-operations which have it as their basis are given with it.
english_pears: If we are given a proposition, then with it we are also given the results of all truth-operations that have it as their base.

text: 5.45 If there are primitive logical signs, then any logic that fails to show clearly how they are placed relatively to one another and to justify their existence will be incorrect. The construction of logic out of its primitive signs must be made clear.
german: Gibt es logische Urzeichen, so muss eine richtige Logik ihre Stellung zueinander klar machen und ihr Dasein rechtfertigen. Der Bau der Logik aus ihren Urzeichen muss klar werden.
english_ogden: If there are logical primitive signs a correct logic must make clear their position relative to one another and justify their existence. The construction of logic out of its primitive signs must become clear.
english_pears: If there are primitive logical signs, then any logic that fails to show clearly how they are placed relatively to one another and to justify their existence will be incorrect. The construction of logic out of its primitive signs must be made clear.

text: 5.451 If logic has primitive ideas, they must be independent of one another. If a primitive idea has been introduced, it must have been introduced in all the combinations in which it ever occurs. It cannot, therefore, be introduced first for one combination and later reintroduced for another. For example, once negation has been introduced, we must understand it both in propositions of the form ‘~p’ and in propositions like ‘~(p∨q)’, ‘(∃x).~fx’, etc. We must not introduce it first for the one class of cases and then for the other, since it would then be left in doubt whether its meaning were the same in both cases, and no reason would have been given for combining the signs in the same way in both cases.
german: Hat die Logik Grundbegriffe, so müssen sie von einander unabhängig sein. Ist ein Grundbegriff eingeführt, so muss er in allen Verbindungen eingeführt sein, worin er überhaupt vorkommt. Man kann ihn also nicht zuerst für eine Verbindung, dann noch einmal für eine andere einführen. Z. B.: Ist die Verneinung eingeführt, so müssen wir sie jetzt in Sätzen von der Form „~p“ ebenso verstehen, wie in Sätzen wie „~(p∨q)“, „(∃x).~fx“ u. a. Wir dürfen sie nicht erst für die eine Klasse von Fällen, dann für die andere einführen, denn es bliebe dann zweifelhaft, ob ihre Bedeutung in beiden Fällen die gleiche wäre und es wäre kein Grund vorhanden, in beiden Fällen dieselbe Art der Zeichenverbindung zu benützen.
english_ogden: If logic has primitive ideas these must be independent of one another. If a primitive idea is introduced it must be introduced in all contexts in which it occurs at all. One cannot therefore introduce it for one context and then again for another. For example, if denial is introduced, we must understand it in propositions of the form “~p”, just as in propositions like “~(p∨q)”, “(∃x).~fx” and others. We may not first introduce it for one class of cases and then for another, for it would then remain doubtful whether its meaning in the two cases was the same, and there would be no reason to use the same way of symbolizing in the two cases.
english_pears: If logic has primitive ideas, they must be independent of one another. If a primitive idea has been introduced, it must have been introduced in all the combinations in which it ever occurs. It cannot, therefore, be introduced first for one combination and later reintroduced for another. For example, once negation has been introduced, we must understand it both in propositions of the form ‘~p’ and in propositions like ‘~(p∨q)’, ‘(∃x).~fx’, etc. We must not introduce it first for the one class of cases and then for the other, since it would then be left in doubt whether its meaning were the same in both cases, and no reason would have been given for combining the signs in the same way in both cases.

text: 5.452 The introduction of any new device into the symbolism of logic is necessarily a momentous event. In logic a new device should not be introduced in brackets or in a footnote with what one might call a completely innocent air.
german: Die Einführung eines neuen Behelfes in den Symbolismus der Logik muss immer ein folgenschweres Ereignis sein. Kein neuer Behelf darf in die Logik – sozusagen, mit ganz unschuldiger Miene – in Klammern oder unter dem Striche eingeführt werden.
english_ogden: The introduction of a new expedient in the symbolism of logic must always be an event full of consequences. No new symbol may be introduced in logic in brackets or in the margin—with, so to speak, an entirely innocent face.
english_pears: The introduction of any new device into the symbolism of logic is necessarily a momentous event. In logic a new device should not be introduced in brackets or in a footnote with what one might call a completely innocent air.

text: 5.453 All numbers in logic stand in need of justification.
german: Alle Zahlen der Logik müssen sich rechtfertigen lassen.
english_ogden: All numbers in logic must be capable of justification.
english_pears: All numbers in logic stand in need of justification.

text: 5.454 In logic there is no co-ordinate status, and there can be no classification.
german: In der Logik gibt es kein Nebeneinander, kann es keine Klassifikation geben.
english_ogden: In logic there is no side by side, there can be no classification.
english_pears: In logic there is no co-ordinate status, and there can be no classification.

text: 5.4541 The solutions of the problems of logic must be simple, since they set the standard of simplicity.
german: Die Lösungen der logischen Probleme müssen einfach sein, denn sie setzen den Standard der Einfachheit.
english_ogden: The solution of logical problems must be neat for they set the standard of neatness.
english_pears: The solutions of the problems of logic must be simple, since they set the standard of simplicity.

text: 5.46 If we introduced logical signs properly, then we should also have introduced at the same time the sense of all combinations of them; i.e. not only ‘p∨q’ but ‘~(p∨~q)’ as well, etc. etc. We should also have introduced at the same time the effect of all possible combinations of brackets. And thus it would have been made clear that the real general primitive signs are not ‘p∨q’, ‘(∃x).fx’, etc. but the most general form of their combinations.
german: Wenn man die logischen Zeichen richtig einführte, so hätte man damit auch schon den Sinn aller ihrer Kombinationen eingeführt; also nicht nur „p∨q“ sondern auch schon „~(p∨~q)“ etc. etc. Man hätte damit auch schon die Wirkung aller nur möglichen Kombinationen von Klammern eingeführt. Und damit wäre es klar geworden, dass die eigentlichen allgemeinen Urzeichen nicht die „p∨q “, „(∃x).fx“, etc. sind, sondern die allgemeinste Form ihrer Kombinationen.
english_ogden: When we have rightly introduced the logical signs, the sense of all their combinations has been already introduced with them: therefore not only “p∨q” but also “~(p∨~q)”, etc. etc. We should then already have introduced the effect of all possible combinations of brackets; and it would then have become clear that the proper general primitive signs are not “p∨q”, “(∃x).fx”, etc., but the most general form of their combinations.
english_pears: If we introduced logical signs properly, then we should also have introduced at the same time the sense of all combinations of them; i.e. not only ‘p∨q’ but ‘~(p∨~q)’ as well, etc. etc. We should also have introduced at the same time the effect of all possible combinations of brackets. And thus it would have been made clear that the real general primitive signs are not ‘p∨q’, ‘(∃x).fx’, etc. but the most general form of their combinations.

text: 5.461 Though it seems unimportant, it is in fact significant that the pseudo-relations of logic, such as ∨ and ⊃, need brackets—unlike real relations.
german: Bedeutungsvoll ist die scheinbar unwichtige Tatsache, dass die logischen Scheinbeziehungen, wie ∨ und ⊃, der Klammern bedürfen – im Gegensatz zu den wirklichen Beziehungen.
english_ogden: The apparently unimportant fact that the apparent relations like ∨ and ⊃ need brackets—unlike real relations—is of great importance.
english_pears: Though it seems unimportant, it is in fact significant that the pseudo-relations of logic, such as ∨ and ⊃, need brackets—unlike real relations.

text: 5.4611 Signs for logical operations are punctuation-marks.
german: Die logischen Operationszeichen sind Interpunktionen.
english_ogden: Logical operation signs are punctuations.
english_pears: Signs for logical operations are punctuation-marks.

text: 5.47 It is clear that whatever we can say in advance about the form of all propositions, we must be able to say all at once.
german: Es ist klar, dass alles, was sich überhaupt von vornherein über die Form aller Sätze sagen lässt, sich auf einmal sagen lassen muss.
english_ogden: It is clear that everything which can be said beforehand about the form of all propositions at all can be said on one occasion.
english_pears: It is clear that whatever we can say in advance about the form of all propositions, we must be able to say all at once.

text: 5.471 The general propositional form is the essence of a proposition.
german: Die allgemeine Satzform ist das Wesen des Satzes.
english_ogden: The general form of proposition is the essence of proposition.
english_pears: The general propositional form is the essence of a proposition.

text: 5.4711 To give the essence of a proposition means to give the essence of all description, and thus the essence of the world.
german: Das Wesen des Satzes angeben, heißt, das Wesen aller Beschreibung angeben, also das Wesen der Welt.
english_ogden: To give the essence of proposition means to give the essence of all description, therefore the essence of the world.
english_pears: To give the essence of a proposition means to give the essence of all description, and thus the essence of the world.
