text: 5.472 The description of the most general propositional form is the description of the one and only general primitive sign in logic.
german: Die Beschreibung der allgemeinsten Satzform ist die Beschreibung des einen und einzigen allgemeinen Urzeichens der Logik.
english_ogden: The description of the most general propositional form is the description of the one and only general primitive sign in logic.
english_pears: The description of the most general propositional form is the description of the one and only general primitive sign in logic.

text: 5.473 Logic must look after itself.
german: Die Logik muss für sich selber sorgen.
english_ogden: Logic must take care of itself.
english_pears: Logic must look after itself.

text: 5.4731 Self-evidence, which Russell talked about so much, can become dispensable in logic, only because language itself prevents every logical mistake.—What makes logic a priori is the impossibility of illogical thought.
german: Das Einleuchten, von dem Russell so viel sprach, kann nur dadurch in der Logik entbehrlich werden, dass die Sprache selbst jeden logischen Fehler verhindert. – Dass die Logik a priori ist, besteht darin, dass nicht unlogisch gedacht werden kann.
english_ogden: Self-evidence, of which Russell has said so much, can only be discarded in logic by language itself preventing every logical mistake. That logic is a priori consists in the fact that we cannot think illogically.
english_pears: Self-evidence, which Russell talked about so much, can become dispensable in logic, only because language itself prevents every logical mistake.—What makes logic a priori is the impossibility of illogical thought.

text: 5.4732 We cannot give a sign the wrong sense.
german: Wir können einem Zeichen nicht den unrechten Sinn geben.
english_ogden: We cannot give a sign the wrong sense.
english_pears: We cannot give a sign the wrong sense.

text: 5.47321 Occam’s maxim is, of course, not an arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its success in practice: its point is that unnecessary units in a sign-language mean nothing.
german: Occams Devise ist natürlich keine willkürliche, oder durch ihren praktischen Erfolg gerechtfertigte Regel: Sie besagt, dass unnötige Zeicheneinheiten nichts bedeuten.
english_ogden: Occam’s razor is, of course, not an arbitrary rule nor one justified by its practical success. It simply says that unnecessary elements in a symbolism mean nothing.
english_pears: Occam’s maxim is, of course, not an arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its success in practice: its point is that unnecessary units in a sign-language mean nothing.

text: 5.4733 Frege says that any legitimately constructed proposition must have a sense. And I say that any possible proposition is legitimately constructed, and, if it has no sense, that can only be because we have failed to give a meaning to some of its constituents.
german: Frege sagt: Jeder rechtmäßig gebildete Satz muss einen Sinn haben; und ich sage: Jeder mögliche Satz ist rechtmäßig gebildet, und wenn er keinen Sinn hat, so kann das nur daran liegen, dass wir einigen seiner Bestandteile keine Bedeutung gegeben haben.
english_ogden: Frege says: Every legitimately constructed proposition must have a sense; and I say: Every possible proposition is legitimately constructed, and if it has no sense this can only be because we have given no meaning to some of its constituent parts.
english_pears: Frege says that any legitimately constructed proposition must have a sense. And I say that any possible proposition is legitimately constructed, and, if it has no sense, that can only be because we have failed to give a meaning to some of its constituents.

text: 5.474 The number of fundamental operations that are necessary depends solely on our notation.
german: Die Anzahl der nötigen Grundoperationen hängt nur von unserer Notation ab.
english_ogden: The number of necessary fundamental operations depends only on our notation.
english_pears: The number of fundamental operations that are necessary depends solely on our notation.

text: 5.475 All that is required is that we should construct a system of signs with a particular number of dimensions—with a particular mathematical multiplicity.
german: Es kommt nur darauf an, ein Zeichensystem von einer bestimmten Anzahl von Dimensionen – von einer bestimmten mathematischen Mannigfaltigkeit – zu bilden.
english_ogden: It is only a question of constructing a system of signs of a definite number of dimensions—of a definite mathematical multiplicity.
english_pears: All that is required is that we should construct a system of signs with a particular number of dimensions—with a particular mathematical multiplicity.

text: 5.476 It is clear that this is not a question of a number of primitive ideas that have to be signified, but rather of the expression of a rule.
german: Es ist klar, dass es sich hier nicht um eine Anzahl von Grundbegriffen handelt, die bezeichnet werden müssen, sondern um den Ausdruck einer Regel.
english_ogden: It is clear that we are not concerned here with a number of primitive ideas which must be signified but with the expression of a rule.
english_pears: It is clear that this is not a question of a number of primitive ideas that have to be signified, but rather of the expression of a rule.

text: 5.5 Every truth-function is a result of successive applications to elementary propositions of the operation ‘(−−−−−T) (ξ, . . . . .)’.
german: Jede Wahrheitsfunktion ist ein Resultat der successiven Anwendung der Operation (−−−−−W) (ξ, . . . . .) auf Elementarsätze.
english_ogden: Every truth-function is a result of the successive application of the operation (−−−−−T) (ξ, . . . . .) to elementary propositions.
english_pears: Every truth-function is a result of successive applications to elementary propositions of the operation ‘(−−−−−T) (ξ, . . . . .)’.

text: 5.501 When a bracketed expression has propositions as its terms—and the order of the terms inside the brackets is indifferent—then I indicate it by a sign of the form ‘(ξ)’. ‘ξ’ is a variable whose values are terms of the bracketed expression and the bar over the variable indicates that it is the representative of all its values in the brackets.
german: Einen Klammerausdruck, dessen Glieder Sätze sind, deute ich – wenn die Reihenfolge der Glieder in der Klammer gleichgültig ist – durch ein Zeichen von der Form „(ξ)“ an. „ξ“ ist eine Variable, deren Werte die Glieder des Klammerausdruckes sind; und der Strich über der Variablen deutet an, dass sie ihre sämtlichen Werte in der Klammer vertritt.
english_ogden: An expression in brackets whose terms are propositions I indicate—if the order of the terms in the bracket is indifferent—by a sign of the form “(ξ)”. “ξ” is a variable whose values are the terms of the expression in brackets, and the line over the variable indicates that it stands for all its values in the bracket.
english_pears: When a bracketed expression has propositions as its terms—and the order of the terms inside the brackets is indifferent—then I indicate it by a sign of the form ‘(ξ)’. ‘ξ’ is a variable whose values are terms of the bracketed expression and the bar over the variable indicates that it is the representative of all its values in the brackets.

text: 5.502 So instead of ‘(−−−−−T) (ξ, . . . . .)’, I write ‘N(ξ)’.
german: Ich schreibe also statt „(−−−−−W) (ξ, . . . . .)“ „N(ξ)“.
english_ogden: Therefore I write instead of “(−−−−−T) (ξ, . . . . .)”, “N(ξ)”.
english_pears: So instead of ‘(−−−−−T) (ξ, . . . . .)’, I write ‘N(ξ)’.

text: 5.503 It is obvious that we can easily express how propositions may be constructed with this operation, and how they may not be constructed with it; so it must be possible to find an exact expression for this.
german: Da sich offenbar leicht ausdrücken lässt, wie mit dieser Operation Sätze gebildet werden können und wie Sätze mit ihr nicht zu bilden sind, so muss dies auch einen exakten Ausdruck finden können.
english_ogden: As it is obviously easy to express how propositions can be constructed by means of this operation and how propositions are not to be constructed by means of it, this must be capable of exact expression.
english_pears: It is obvious that we can easily express how propositions may be constructed with this operation, and how they may not be constructed with it; so it must be possible to find an exact expression for this.

text: 5.51 If ξ has only one value, then N(ξ)=~p (not p); if it has two values, then N (ξ)=~p.~q (neither p nor q).
german: Hat ξ nur einen Wert, so ist N(ξ)=~p (nicht p), hat es zwei Werte, so ist N (ξ)=~p.~q (weder p noch q).
english_ogden: If ξ has only one value, then N(ξ)=~p (not p), if it has two values then N (ξ)=~p.~q (neither p nor q).
english_pears: If ξ has only one value, then N(ξ)=~p (not p); if it has two values, then N (ξ)=~p.~q (neither p nor q).

text: 5.511 How can logic—all-embracing logic, which mirrors the world—use such peculiar crotchets and contrivances? Only because they are all connected with one another in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.
german: Wie kann die allumfassende, weltspiegelnde Logik so spezielle Haken und Manipulationen gebrauchen? Nur, indem sich alle diese zu einem unendlich feinen Netzwerk, zu dem großen Spiegel, verknüpfen.
english_ogden: How can the all-embracing logic which mirrors the world use such special catches and manipulations? Only because all these are connected into an infinitely fine network, to the great mirror.
english_pears: How can logic—all-embracing logic, which mirrors the world—use such peculiar crotchets and contrivances? Only because they are all connected with one another in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

text: 5.512 ‘~p’ is true if ‘p’ is false. Therefore, in the proposition ‘~p’, when it is true, ‘p’ is a false proposition. How then can the stroke ‘~’ make it agree with reality?
german: „~p“ ist wahr, wenn „p“ falsch ist. Also in dem wahren Satz „~p“ ist „p“ ein falscher Satz. Wie kann ihn nun der Strich „~“ mit der Wirklichkeit zum Stimmen bringen?
english_ogden: “~p” is true if “p” is false. Therefore in the true proposition “~p” “p” is a false proposition. How then can the stroke “~” bring it into agreement with reality?
english_pears: ‘~p’ is true if ‘p’ is false. Therefore, in the proposition ‘~p’, when it is true, ‘p’ is a false proposition. How then can the stroke ‘~’ make it agree with reality?

text: 5.513 We might say that what is common to all symbols that affirm both p and q is the proposition ‘p.q’; and that what is common to all symbols that affirm either p or q is the proposition ‘p∨q’.
german: Man könnte sagen: Das Gemeinsame aller Symbole, die sowohl p als q bejahen, ist der Satz „p.q“. Das Gemeinsame aller Symbole, die entweder p oder q bejahen, ist der Satz „p∨q“.
english_ogden: We could say: What is common to all symbols, which assert both p and q, is the proposition “p.q”. What is common to all symbols, which asserts either p or q, is the proposition “p∨q”.
english_pears: We might say that what is common to all symbols that affirm both p and q is the proposition ‘p.q’; and that what is common to all symbols that affirm either p or q is the proposition ‘p∨q’.

text: 5.514 Once a notation has been established, there will be in it a rule governing the construction of all propositions that negate p, a rule governing the construction of all propositions that affirm p, and a rule governing the construction of all propositions that affirm p or q; and so on. These rules are equivalent to the symbols; and in them their sense is mirrored.
german: Ist eine Notation festgelegt, so gibt es in ihr eine Regel, nach der alle p verneinenden Sätze gebildet werden, eine Regel, nach der alle p bejahenden Sätze gebildet werden, eine Regel, nach der alle p oder q bejahenden Sätze gebildet werden, u. s. f. Diese Regeln sind den Symbolen äquivalent und in ihnen spiegelt sich ihr Sinn wieder.
english_ogden: If a notation is fixed, there is in it a rule according to which all the propositions denying p are constructed, a rule according to which all the propositions asserting p are constructed, a rule according to which all the propositions asserting p or q are constructed, and so on. These rules are equivalent to the symbols and in them their sense is mirrored.
english_pears: Once a notation has been established, there will be in it a rule governing the construction of all propositions that negate p, a rule governing the construction of all propositions that affirm p, and a rule governing the construction of all propositions that affirm p or q; and so on. These rules are equivalent to the symbols; and in them their sense is mirrored.

text: 5.515 It must be manifest in our symbols that it can only be propositions that are combined with one another by ‘∨’, ‘.’, etc.
german: Es muss sich an unseren Symbolen zeigen, dass das, was durch „∨“, „.“, etc. miteinander verbunden ist, Sätze sein müssen.
english_ogden: It must be recognized in our symbols that what is connected by “∨”, “.”, etc., must be propositions.
english_pears: It must be manifest in our symbols that it can only be propositions that are combined with one another by ‘∨’, ‘.’, etc.

text: 5.5151 Must the sign of a negative proposition be constructed with that of the positive proposition? Why should it not be possible to express a negative proposition by means of a negative fact? (E.g. suppose that ‘a’ does not stand in a certain relation to ‘b’; then this might be used to say that aRb was not the case.)
german: Muss das Zeichen des negativen Satzes mit dem Zeichen des positiven gebildet werden? Warum sollte man den negativen Satz nicht durch eine negative Tatsache ausdrücken können. (Etwa: Wenn „a“ nicht in einer bestimmten Beziehung zu „b“ steht, könnte das ausdrücken, dass aRb nicht der Fall ist.)
english_ogden: Must the sign of the negative proposition be constructed by means of the sign of the positive? Why should one not be able to express the negative proposition by means of a negative fact? (Like: if “a” does not stand in a certain relation to “b”, it could express that aRb is not the case.)
english_pears: Must the sign of a negative proposition be constructed with that of the positive proposition? Why should it not be possible to express a negative proposition by means of a negative fact? (E.g. suppose that ‘a’ does not stand in a certain relation to ‘b’; then this might be used to say that aRb was not the case.)

text: 5.52 If ξ has as its values all the values of a function fx for all values of x, then N(ξ)=~(∃x).fx.
german: Sind die Werte von ξ sämtliche Werte einer Funktion fx für alle Werte von x, so wird N(ξ)=~(∃x).fx.
english_ogden: If the values of ξ are the total values of a function fx for all values of x, then N(ξ)=~(∃x).fx.
english_pears: If ξ has as its values all the values of a function fx for all values of x, then N(ξ)=~(∃x).fx.

text: 5.521 I dissociate the concept all from truth-functions.
german: Ich trenne den Begriff Alle von der Wahrheitsfunktion.
english_ogden: I separate the concept all from the truth-function.
english_pears: I dissociate the concept all from truth-functions.

text: 5.522 What is peculiar to the generality-sign is first, that it indicates a logical prototype, and secondly, that it gives prominence to constants.
german: Das Eigentümliche der Allgemeinheitsbezeichnung ist erstens, dass sie auf ein logisches Urbild hinweist, und zweitens, dass sie Konstante hervorhebt.
english_ogden: That which is peculiar to the “symbolism of generality” is firstly, that it refers to a logical prototype, and secondly, that it makes constants prominent.
english_pears: What is peculiar to the generality-sign is first, that it indicates a logical prototype, and secondly, that it gives prominence to constants.

text: 5.523 The generality-sign occurs as an argument.
german: Die Allgemeinheitsbezeichnung tritt als Argument auf.
english_ogden: The generality symbol occurs as an argument.
english_pears: The generality-sign occurs as an argument.

text: 5.524 If objects are given, then at the same time we are given all objects.
german: Wenn die Gegenstände gegeben sind, so sind uns damit auch schon alle Gegenstände gegeben.
english_ogden: If the objects are given, therewith are all objects also given.
english_pears: If objects are given, then at the same time we are given all objects.

text: 5.525 It is incorrect to render the proposition ‘(∃x).fx’ in the words, ‘fx is possible’ as Russell does.
german: Es ist unrichtig, den Satz „(∃x).fx“ – wie Russell dies tut – in Worten durch „fx ist möglich“ wiederzugeben.
english_ogden: It is not correct to render the proposition “(∃x).fx”—as Russell does—in the words “fx is possible”.
english_pears: It is incorrect to render the proposition ‘(∃x).fx’ in the words, ‘fx is possible’ as Russell does.

text: 5.526 We can describe the world completely by means of fully generalized propositions, i.e. without first correlating any name with a particular object.
german: Man kann die Welt vollständig durch vollkommen verallgemeinerte Sätze beschreiben, das heißt also, ohne irgendeinen Namen von vornherein einem bestimmten Gegenstand zuzuordnen.
english_ogden: One can describe the world completely by completely generalized propositions, i.e. without from the outset co-ordinating any name with a definite object.
english_pears: We can describe the world completely by means of fully generalized propositions, i.e. without first correlating any name with a particular object.

text: 5.5261 A fully generalized proposition, like every other proposition, is composite. (This is shown by the fact that in ‘(∃x, φ).φx’ we have to mention ‘φ’ and ‘x’ separately. They both, independently, stand in signifying relations to the world, just as is the case in ungeneralized propositions.)
german: Ein vollkommen verallgemeinerter Satz ist, wie jeder andere Satz, zusammengesetzt. (Dies zeigt sich daran, dass wir in „(∃x, φ).φx“ „φ“ und „x“ getrennt erwähnen müssen. Beide stehen unabhängig in bezeichnenden Beziehungen zur Welt, wie im unverallgemeinerten Satz.)
english_ogden: A completely generalized proposition is like every other proposition composite. (This is shown by the fact that in “(∃x, φ).φx” we must mention “φ” and “x” separately. Both stand independently in signifying relations to the world as in the ungeneralized proposition.)
english_pears: A fully generalized proposition, like every other proposition, is composite. (This is shown by the fact that in ‘(∃x, φ).φx’ we have to mention ‘φ’ and ‘x’ separately. They both, independently, stand in signifying relations to the world, just as is the case in ungeneralized propositions.)

text: 5.5262 The truth or falsity of every proposition does make some alteration in the general construction of the world. And the range that the totality of elementary propositions leaves open for its construction is exactly the same as that which is delimited by entirely general propositions.
german: Es verändert ja die Wahr- oder Falschheit jedes Satzes etwas am allgemeinen Bau der Welt. Und der Spielraum, welcher ihrem Bau durch die Gesamtheit der Elementarsätze gelassen wird, ist eben derjenige, welchen die ganz allgemeinen Sätze begrenzen.
english_ogden: The truth or falsehood of every proposition alters something in the general structure of the world. And the range which is allowed to its structure by the totality of elementary propositions is exactly that which the completely general propositions delimit.
english_pears: The truth or falsity of every proposition does make some alteration in the general construction of the world. And the range that the totality of elementary propositions leaves open for its construction is exactly the same as that which is delimited by entirely general propositions.

text: 5.53 Identity of object I express by identity of sign, and not by using a sign for identity. Difference of objects I express by difference of signs.
german: Gleichheit des Gegenstandes drücke ich durch Gleichheit des Zeichens aus, und nicht mit Hilfe eines Gleichheitszeichens. Verschiedenheit der Gegenstände durch Verschiedenheit der Zeichen.
english_ogden: Identity of the object I express by identity of the sign and not by means of a sign of identity. Difference of the objects by difference of the signs.
english_pears: Identity of object I express by identity of sign, and not by using a sign for identity. Difference of objects I express by difference of signs.

text: 5.5301 It is self-evident that identity is not a relation between objects. This becomes very clear if one considers, for example, the proposition ‘(x):fx.⊃.x=a’. What this proposition says is simply that only a satisfies the function f, and not that only things that have a certain relation to a satisfy the function f.
german: Dass die Identität keine Relation zwischen Gegenständen ist, leuchtet ein. Dies wird sehr klar, wenn man z. B. den Satz „(x):fx.⊃.x=a“ betrachtet. Was dieser Satz sagt, ist einfach, dass nur a der Funktion f genügt, und nicht, dass nur solche Dinge der Funktion f genügen, welche eine gewisse Beziehung zu a haben.
english_ogden: That identity is not a relation between objects is obvious. This becomes very clear if, for example, one considers the proposition “(x):fx.⊃.x=a”. What this proposition says is simply that only a satisfies the function f, and not that only such things satisfy the function f which have a certain relation to a.
english_pears: It is self-evident that identity is not a relation between objects. This becomes very clear if one considers, for example, the proposition ‘(x):fx.⊃.x=a’. What this proposition says is simply that only a satisfies the function f, and not that only things that have a certain relation to a satisfy the function f.

text: 5.5302 Russell’s definition of ‘=’ is inadequate, because according to it we cannot say that two objects have all their properties in common. (Even if this proposition is never correct, it still has sense.)
german: Russells Definition von „=“ genügt nicht; weil man nach ihr nicht sagen kann, dass zwei Gegenstände alle Eigenschaften gemeinsam haben. (Selbst wenn dieser Satz nie richtig ist, hat er doch Sinn.)
english_ogden: Russell’s definition of “=” won’t do; because according to it one cannot say that two objects have all their properties in common. (Even if this proposition is never true, it is nevertheless significant.)
english_pears: Russell’s definition of ‘=’ is inadequate, because according to it we cannot say that two objects have all their properties in common. (Even if this proposition is never correct, it still has sense.)

text: 5.5303 Roughly speaking, to say of two things that they are identical is nonsense, and to say of one thing that it is identical with itself is to say nothing at all.
german: Beiläufig gesprochen: Von zwei Dingen zu sagen, sie seien identisch, ist ein Unsinn, und von Einem zu sagen, es sei identisch mit sich selbst, sagt gar nichts.
english_ogden: Roughly speaking: to say of two things that they are identical is nonsense, and to say of one thing that it is identical with itself is to say nothing.
english_pears: Roughly speaking, to say of two things that they are identical is nonsense, and to say of one thing that it is identical with itself is to say nothing at all.

text: 5.531 Thus I do not write ‘f(a,b).a=b’, but ‘f(a,a)’ (or ‘f(b,b)’); and not ‘f(a,b).~a=b’, but ‘f(a,b)’.
german: Ich schreibe also nicht „f(a,b).a=b“, sondern „f(a,a)“ (oder „f(b,b)“). Und nicht „f(a,b).~a=b“, sondern „f(a,b)“.
english_ogden: I write therefore not “f(a,b).a=b” but “f(a,a)” (or “f(b,b)”). And not “f(a,b).~a=b”, but “f(a,b)”.
english_pears: Thus I do not write ‘f(a,b).a=b’, but ‘f(a,a)’ (or ‘f(b,b)’); and not ‘f(a,b).~a=b’, but ‘f(a,b)’.

text: 5.532 And analogously I do not write ‘(∃x,y).f(x,y).x=y’, but ‘(∃x).f(x,x)’; and not ‘(∃x,y).f(x,y).~x=y’, but ‘(∃x,y).f(x,y)’.
german: Und analog: Nicht „(∃x,y).f(x,y).x=y“, sondern „(∃x).f(x,x)“; und nicht „(∃x,y).f(x,y).~x=y“, sondern „(∃x,y).f(x,y)“.
english_ogden: And analogously: not “(∃x,y).f(x,y).x=y”, but “(∃x).f(x,x)”; and not “(∃x,y).f(x,y).~x=y”, but “(∃x,y).f(x,y)”.
english_pears: And analogously I do not write ‘(∃x,y).f(x,y).x=y’, but ‘(∃x).f(x,x)’; and not ‘(∃x,y).f(x,y).~x=y’, but ‘(∃x,y).f(x,y)’.

text: 5.5321 Thus, for example, instead of ‘(x):fx⊃x=a’ we write ‘(∃x).fx.⊃.fa:~(∃x,y).fx.fy’.
german: Statt „(x):fx⊃x=a“ schreiben wir also z. B. „(∃x).fx.⊃.fa:~(∃x,y).fx.fy“.
english_ogden: Instead of “(x):fx⊃x=a” we therefore write e.g. “(∃x).fx.⊃.fa:~(∃x,y).fx.fy”.
english_pears: Thus, for example, instead of ‘(x):fx⊃x=a’ we write ‘(∃x).fx.⊃.fa:~(∃x,y).fx.fy’.

text: 5.533 The identity-sign, therefore, is not an essential constituent of conceptual notation.
german: Das Gleichheitszeichen ist also kein wesentlicher Bestandteil der Begriffsschrift.
english_ogden: The identity sign is therefore not an essential constituent of logical notation.
english_pears: The identity-sign, therefore, is not an essential constituent of conceptual notation.

text: 5.534 And now we see that in a correct conceptual notation pseudo-propositions like ‘a=a’, ‘a=b.b=c.⊃a=c’, ‘(x).x=x’, ‘(∃x).x=a’, etc. cannot even be written down.
german: Und nun sehen wir, dass Scheinsätze wie: „a=a“, „a=b.b=c.⊃a=c“, „(x).x=x“, „(∃x).x=a“, etc. sich in einer richtigen Begriffsschrift gar nicht hinschreiben lassen.
english_ogden: And we see that the apparent propositions like: “a=a”, “a=b.b=c.⊃a=c”, “(x).x=x”. “(∃x).x=a”, etc. cannot be written in a correct logical notation at all.
english_pears: And now we see that in a correct conceptual notation pseudo-propositions like ‘a=a’, ‘a=b.b=c.⊃a=c’, ‘(x).x=x’, ‘(∃x).x=a’, etc. cannot even be written down.

text: 5.535 This also disposes of all the problems that were connected with such pseudo-propositions.
german: Damit erledigen sich auch alle Probleme, die an solche Scheinsätze geknüpft waren.
english_ogden: So all problems disappear which are connected with such pseudo-propositions.
english_pears: This also disposes of all the problems that were connected with such pseudo-propositions.

text: 5.5351 There are certain cases in which one is tempted to use expressions of the form ‘a=a’ or ‘p⊃p’ and the like. In fact, this happens when one wants to talk about prototypes, e.g. about proposition, thing, etc. Thus in Russell’s Principles of Mathematics ‘p is a proposition’—which is nonsense—was given the symbolic rendering ‘p⊃p’ and placed as an hypothesis in front of certain propositions in order to exclude from their argument-places everything but propositions.
german: Es gibt gewisse Fälle, wo man in Versuchung gerät, Ausdrücke von der Form „a=a“ oder „p⊃p“ u. dgl. zu benützen. Und zwar geschieht dies, wenn man von dem Urbild: Satz, Ding, etc. reden möchte. So hat Russell in den „Principles of Mathematics“ den Unsinn „p ist ein Satz“ in Symbolen durch „p⊃p“ wiedergegeben und als Hypothese vor gewisse Sätze gestellt, damit deren Argumentstellen nur von Sätzen besetzt werden könnten.
english_ogden: There are certain cases in which one is tempted to use expressions of the form “a=a” or “p⊃p”. As, for instance, when one would speak of the archetype Proposition, Thing, etc. So Russell in the Principles of Mathematics has rendered the nonsense “p is a proposition” in symbols by “p⊃p” and has put it as hypothesis before certain propositions to show that their places for arguments could only be occupied by propositions.
english_pears: There are certain cases in which one is tempted to use expressions of the form ‘a=a’ or ‘p⊃p’ and the like. In fact, this happens when one wants to talk about prototypes, e.g. about proposition, thing, etc. Thus in Russell’s Principles of Mathematics ‘p is a proposition’—which is nonsense—was given the symbolic rendering ‘p⊃p’ and placed as an hypothesis in front of certain propositions in order to exclude from their argument-places everything but propositions.

text: 5.5352 In the same way people have wanted to express, ‘There are no things’, by writing ‘~(∃x).x=x’. But even if this were a proposition, would it not be equally true if in fact ‘there were things’ but they were not identical with themselves?
german: Ebenso wollte man „Es gibt keine Dinge“ ausdrücken durch „~(∃x).x=x“. Aber selbst wenn dies ein Satz wäre – wäre er nicht auch wahr, wenn es zwar „Dinge gäbe“, aber diese nicht mit sich selbst identisch wären?
english_ogden: Similarly it was proposed to express “There are no things” by “~(∃x).x=x”. But even if this were a proposition—would it not be true if indeed “There were things”, but these were not identical with themselves?
english_pears: In the same way people have wanted to express, ‘There are no things’, by writing ‘~(∃x).x=x’. But even if this were a proposition, would it not be equally true if in fact ‘there were things’ but they were not identical with themselves?

text: 5.54 In the general propositional form propositions occur in other propositions only as bases of truth-operations.
german: In der allgemeinen Satzform kommt der Satz im Satze nur als Basis der Wahrheitsoperationen vor.
english_ogden: In the general propositional form, propositions occur in a proposition only as bases of the truth-operations.
english_pears: In the general propositional form propositions occur in other propositions only as bases of truth-operations.

text: 5.541 At first sight it looks as if it were also possible for one proposition to occur in another in a different way.
german: Auf den ersten Blick scheint es, als könne ein Satz in einem anderen auch auf andere Weise vorkommen.
english_ogden: At first sight it appears as if there were also a different way in which one proposition could occur in another.
english_pears: At first sight it looks as if it were also possible for one proposition to occur in another in a different way.

text: 5.542 It is clear, however, that ‘A believes that p’, ‘A has the thought p’, and ‘A says p’ are of the form ‘“p” says p’: and this does not involve a correlation of a fact with an object, but rather the correlation of facts by means of the correlation of their objects.
german: Es ist aber klar, dass „A glaubt, dass p“, „A denkt p“, „A sagt p“ von der Form „‚p‘ sagt p“ sind: Und hier handelt es sich nicht um eine Zuordnung von einer Tatsache und einem Gegenstand, sondern um die Zuordnung von Tatsachen durch Zuordnung ihrer Gegenstände.
english_ogden: But it is clear that “A believes that p”, “A thinks p”, “A says p”, are of the form “‘p’ says p”: and here we have no co-ordination of a fact and an object, but a co-ordination of facts by means of a co-ordination of their objects.
english_pears: It is clear, however, that ‘A believes that p’, ‘A has the thought p’, and ‘A says p’ are of the form ‘“p” says p’: and this does not involve a correlation of a fact with an object, but rather the correlation of facts by means of the correlation of their objects.

text: 5.5421 This shows too that there is no such thing as the soul—the subject, etc.—as it is conceived in the superficial psychology of the present day.
german: Dies zeigt auch, dass die Seele – das Subjekt etc. – wie sie in der heutigen oberflächlichen Psychologie aufgefasst wird, ein Unding ist.
english_ogden: This shows that there is no such thing as the soul—the subject, etc.—as it is conceived in superficial psychology.
english_pears: This shows too that there is no such thing as the soul—the subject, etc.—as it is conceived in the superficial psychology of the present day.

text: 5.5422 The correct explanation of the form of the proposition, ‘A makes the judgement p’, must show that it is impossible for a judgement to be a piece of nonsense. (Russell’s theory does not satisfy this requirement.)
german: Die richtige Erklärung der Form des Satzes „A urteilt p“ muss zeigen, dass es unmöglich ist, einen Unsinn zu urteilen. (Russells Theorie genügt dieser Bedingung nicht.)
english_ogden: The correct explanation of the form of the proposition “A judges p” must show that it is impossible to judge a nonsense. (Russell’s theory does not satisfy this condition.)
english_pears: The correct explanation of the form of the proposition, ‘A makes the judgement p’, must show that it is impossible for a judgement to be a piece of nonsense. (Russell’s theory does not satisfy this requirement.)

text: 5.5423 To perceive a complex means to perceive that its constituents are related to one another in such and such a way.
german: Einen Komplex wahrnehmen heißt wahrnehmen, dass sich seine Bestandteile so und so zu einander verhalten.
english_ogden: To perceive a complex means to perceive that its constituents are combined in such and such a way.
english_pears: To perceive a complex means to perceive that its constituents are related to one another in such and such a way.

text: 5.55 We now have to answer a priori the question about all the possible forms of elementary propositions.
german: Wir müssen nun die Frage nach allen möglichen Formen der Elementarsätze a priori beantworten.
english_ogden: We must now answer a priori the question as to all possible forms of the elementary propositions.
english_pears: We now have to answer a priori the question about all the possible forms of elementary propositions.

text: 5.551 Our fundamental principle is that whenever a question can be decided by logic at all it must be possible to decide it without more ado.
german: Unser Grundsatz ist, dass jede Frage, die sich überhaupt durch die Logik entscheiden lässt, sich ohne weiteres entscheiden lassen muss.
english_ogden: Our fundamental principle is that every question which can be decided at all by logic can be decided off-hand.
english_pears: Our fundamental principle is that whenever a question can be decided by logic at all it must be possible to decide it without more ado.

text: 5.552 The ‘experience’ that we need in order to understand logic is not that something or other is the state of things, but that something is: that, however, is not an experience.
german: Die „Erfahrung“, die wir zum Verstehen der Logik brauchen, ist nicht die, dass sich etwas so und so verhält, sondern, dass etwas ist: aber das ist eben keine Erfahrung.
english_ogden: The “experience” which we need to understand logic is not that such and such is the case, but that something is; but that is no experience.
english_pears: The ‘experience’ that we need in order to understand logic is not that something or other is the state of things, but that something is: that, however, is not an experience.

text: 5.5521 And if this were not so, how could we apply logic? We might put it in this way: if there would be a logic even if there were no world, how then could there be a logic given that there is a world?
german: Und wenn dies nicht so wäre, wie könnten wir die Logik anwenden? Man könnte sagen: Wenn es eine Logik gäbe, auch wenn es keine Welt gäbe, wie könnte es dann eine Logik geben, da es eine Welt gibt.
english_ogden: And if this were not the case, how could we apply logic? We could say: if there were a logic, even if there were no world, how then could there be a logic, since there is a world?
english_pears: And if this were not so, how could we apply logic? We might put it in this way: if there would be a logic even if there were no world, how then could there be a logic given that there is a world?

text: 5.553 Russell said that there were simple relations between different numbers of things (individuals). But between what numbers? And how is this supposed to be decided?—By experience?
german: Russell sagte, es gäbe einfache Relationen zwischen verschiedenen Anzahlen von Dingen (Individuals). Aber zwischen welchen Anzahlen? Und wie soll sich das entscheiden? – Durch die Erfahrung?
english_ogden: Russell said that there were simple relations between different numbers of things (individuals). But between what numbers? And how should this be decided—by experience?
english_pears: Russell said that there were simple relations between different numbers of things (individuals). But between what numbers? And how is this supposed to be decided?—By experience?

text: 5.554 It would be completely arbitrary to give any specific form.
german: Die Angabe jeder speziellen Form wäre vollkommen willkürlich.
english_ogden: The enumeration of any special forms would be entirely arbitrary.
english_pears: It would be completely arbitrary to give any specific form.

text: 5.5541 It is supposed to be possible to answer a priori the question whether I can get into a position in which I need the sign for a 27-termed relation in order to signify something.
german: Es soll sich a priori angeben lassen, ob ich z. B. in die Lage kommen kann, etwas mit dem Zeichen einer 27-stelligen Relation bezeichnen zu müssen.
english_ogden: How could we decide a priori whether, for example, I can get into a situation in which I need to symbolize with a sign of a 27-termed relation?
english_pears: It is supposed to be possible to answer a priori the question whether I can get into a position in which I need the sign for a 27-termed relation in order to signify something.

text: 5.5542 But is it really legitimate even to ask such a question? Can we set up a form of sign without knowing whether anything can correspond to it?
german: Dürfen wir denn aber überhaupt so fragen? Können wir eine Zeichenform aufstellen und nicht wissen, ob ihr etwas entsprechen könne?
english_ogden: May we then ask this at all? Can we set out a sign form and not know whether anything can correspond to it?
english_pears: But is it really legitimate even to ask such a question? Can we set up a form of sign without knowing whether anything can correspond to it?

text: 5.555 Clearly we have some concept of elementary propositions quite apart from their particular logical forms.
german: Es ist klar, wir haben vom Elementarsatz einen Begriff, abgesehen von seiner besonderen logischen Form.
english_ogden: It is clear that we have a concept of the elementary proposition apart from its special logical form.
english_pears: Clearly we have some concept of elementary propositions quite apart from their particular logical forms.

text: 5.556 There cannot be a hierarchy of the forms of elementary propositions. We can foresee only what we ourselves construct.
german: Eine Hierarchie der Formen der Elementarsätze kann es nicht geben. Nur was wir selbst konstruieren, können wir voraussehen.
english_ogden: There cannot be a hierarchy of the forms of the elementary propositions. Only that which we ourselves construct can we foresee.
english_pears: There cannot be a hierarchy of the forms of elementary propositions. We can foresee only what we ourselves construct.

text: 5.5561 Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects. The limit also makes itself manifest in the totality of elementary propositions.
german: Die empirische Realität ist begrenzt durch die Gesamtheit der Gegenstände. Die Grenze zeigt sich wieder in der Gesamtheit der Elementarsätze.
english_ogden: Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects. The boundary appears again in the totality of elementary propositions.
english_pears: Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects. The limit also makes itself manifest in the totality of elementary propositions.

text: 5.5562 If we know on purely logical grounds that there must be elementary propositions, then everyone who understands propositions in their unanalyzed form must know it.
german: Wissen wir aus rein logischen Gründen, dass es Elementarsätze geben muss, dann muss es jeder wissen, der die Sätze in ihrer unanalysierten Form versteht.
english_ogden: If we know on purely logical grounds, that there must be elementary propositions, then this must be known by everyone who understands propositions in their unanalysed form.
english_pears: If we know on purely logical grounds that there must be elementary propositions, then everyone who understands propositions in their unanalyzed form must know it.

text: 5.5563 In fact, all the propositions of our everyday language, just as they stand, are in perfect logical order.—That utterly simple thing, which we have to formulate here, is not a likeness of the truth, but the truth itself in its entirety.
german: Alle Sätze unserer Umgangssprache sind tatsächlich, so wie sie sind, logisch vollkommen geordnet. – Jenes Einfachste, was wir hier angeben sollen, ist nicht ein Gleichnis der Wahrheit, sondern die volle Wahrheit selbst.
english_ogden: All propositions of our colloquial language are actually, just as they are, logically completely in order. That simple thing which we ought to give here is not a model of the truth but the complete truth itself.
english_pears: In fact, all the propositions of our everyday language, just as they stand, are in perfect logical order.—That utterly simple thing, which we have to formulate here, is not a likeness of the truth, but the truth itself in its entirety.

text: 5.557 The application of logic decides what elementary propositions there are.
german: Die Anwendung der Logik entscheidet darüber, welche Elementarsätze es gibt.
english_ogden: The application of logic decides what elementary propositions there are.
english_pears: The application of logic decides what elementary propositions there are.

text: 5.5571 If I cannot say a priori what elementary propositions there are, then the attempt to do so must lead to obvious nonsense.
german: Wenn ich die Elementarsätze nicht a priori angeben kann, dann muss es zu offenbarem Unsinn führen, sie angeben zu wollen.
english_ogden: If I cannot give elementary propositions a priori then it must lead to obvious nonsense to try to give them.
english_pears: If I cannot say a priori what elementary propositions there are, then the attempt to do so must lead to obvious nonsense.

text: 5.6 The limits of my language mean the limits of my world.
german: Die Grenzen meiner Sprache bedeuten die Grenzen meiner Welt.
english_ogden: The limits of my language mean the limits of my world.
english_pears: The limits of my language mean the limits of my world.

text: 5.61 Logic pervades the world: the limits of the world are also its limits.
german: Die Logik erfüllt die Welt; die Grenzen der Welt sind auch ihre Grenzen.
english_ogden: Logic fills the world: the limits of the world are also its limits.
english_pears: Logic pervades the world: the limits of the world are also its limits.

text: 5.62 This remark provides the key to the problem, how much truth there is in solipsism.
german: Diese Bemerkung gibt den Schlüssel zur Entscheidung der Frage, inwieweit der Solipsismus eine Wahrheit ist.
english_ogden: This remark provides a key to the question, to what extent solipsism is a truth.
english_pears: This remark provides the key to the problem, how much truth there is in solipsism.

text: 5.621 The world and life are one.
german: Die Welt und das Leben sind Eins.
english_ogden: The world and life are one.
english_pears: The world and life are one.

text: 5.63 I am my world. (The microcosm.)
german: Ich bin meine Welt. (Der Mikrokosmos.)
english_ogden: I am my world. (The microcosm.)
english_pears: I am my world. (The microcosm.)

text: 5.631 There is no such thing as the subject that thinks or entertains ideas.
german: Das denkende, vorstellende, Subjekt gibt es nicht.
english_ogden: The thinking, presenting subject; there is no such thing.
english_pears: There is no such thing as the subject that thinks or entertains ideas.

text: 5.632 The subject does not belong to the world: rather, it is a limit of the world.
german: Das Subjekt gehört nicht zur Welt, sondern es ist eine Grenze der Welt.
english_ogden: The subject does not belong to the world but it is a limit of the world.
english_pears: The subject does not belong to the world: rather, it is a limit of the world.

text: 5.633 Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be found?
german: Wo in der Welt ist ein metaphysisches Subjekt zu merken?
english_ogden: Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be noted?
english_pears: Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be found?

text: 5.6331 For the form of the visual field is surely not like this
german: Das Gesichtsfeld hat nämlich nicht etwa eine solche Form:
english_ogden: For the field of sight has not a form like this:

english_pears: All theories that make a proposition of logic appear to have content are false. text: 6.12 The fact that the propositions of logic are tautologies shows the formal—logical—properties of language and the world.

text: 6.124 The propositions of logic describe the scaffolding of the world, or rather they represent it. They have no ‘subject-matter’. This contains the decisive point. We have said that some things are arbitrary in the symbols that we use and that some things are not. In logic it is only the latter that express: but that means that logic is not a field in which we express what we wish with the help of signs, but rather one in which the nature of the natural and inevitable signs speaks for itself. If we know the logical syntax of any sign-language, then we have already been given all the propositions of logic.
german: Die logischen Sätze beschreiben das Gerüst der Welt, oder vielmehr, sie stellen es dar. Sie „handeln“ von nichts. text: 6.341 Newtonian mechanics, for example, imposes a unified form on the description of the world. Let us imagine a white surface with irregular black spots on it. We then say that whatever kind of picture these make, I can always approximate as closely as I wish to the description of it by covering the surface with a sufficiently fine square mesh, and then saying of every square whether it is black or white. In this way I shall have imposed a unified form on the description of the surface. The form is optional, since I could have achieved the same result by using a net with a triangular or hexagonal mesh. Possibly the use of a triangular mesh would have made the description simpler: that is to say, it might be that we could describe the surface more accurately with a coarse triangular mesh than with a fine square mesh (or conversely), and so on. The different nets correspond to different systems for describing the world. Mechanics determines one form of description of the world by saying that all propositions used in the description of the world must be obtained in a given way from a given set of propositions—the axioms of mechanics. It thus supplies the bricks for building the edifice of science, and it says, ‘Any building that you want to erect, whatever it may be, must somehow be constructed with these bricks, and with these alone.’
german: Die Newtonsche Mechanik z. B. bringt die Weltbeschreibung auf eine einheitliche Form. Denken wir uns eine weiße Fläche, auf der unregelmäßige schwarze Flecken wären. Wir sagen nun: Was für ein Bild immer hierdurch entsteht, immer kann ich seiner Beschreibung beliebig nahe kommen, indem ich die Fläche mit einem entsprechend feinen quadratischen Netzwerk bedecke und nun von jedem Quadrat sage, dass es weiß oder schwarz ist. Ich werde auf diese Weise die Beschreibung der Fläche auf eine einheitliche Form gebracht haben. Diese Form ist beliebig, denn ich hätte mit dem gleichen Erfolge ein Netz aus dreieckigen oder sechseckigen Maschen verwenden können. Es kann sein, dass die Beschreibung mit Hilfe eines Dreiecks-Netzes einfacher geworden wäre; das heißt, dass wir die Fläche mit einem gröberen Dreiecks-Netz genauer beschreiben könnten als mit einem feineren quadratischen (oder umgekehrt) usw. Den verschiedenen Netzen entsprechen verschiedene Systeme der Weltbeschreibung. Die Mechanik bestimmt eine Form der Weltbeschreibung, indem sie sagt: Alle Sätze der Weltbeschreibung müssen aus einer Anzahl gegebener Sätze – den mechanischen Axiomen – auf eine gegebene Art und Weise erhalten werden. Hierdurch liefert sie die Bausteine zum Bau des wissenschaftlichen Gebäudes und sagt: Welches Gebäude immer du aufführen willst, jedes musst du irgendwie mit diesen und nur diesen Bausteinen zusammenbringen.
english_ogden: Newtonian mechanics, for example, brings the description of the universe to a unified form. Let us imagine a white surface with irregular black spots. In this way I shall have brought the description of the surface to a unified form. This form is arbitrary, because I could have applied with equal success a net with a triangular or hexagonal mesh. It can happen that the description would have been simpler with the aid of a triangular mesh; that is to say we might have described the surface more accurately with a triangular, and coarser, than with the finer square mesh, or vice versa, and so on. To the different networks correspond different systems of describing the world. Mechanics determine a form of description by saying: All propositions in the description of the world must be obtained in a given way from a number of given propositions—the mechanical axioms. It thus provides the bricks for building the edifice of science, and says: Whatever building thou wouldst erect, thou shalt construct it in some manner with these bricks and these alone.

It thus supplies the bricks for building the edifice of science, and it says, ‘Any building that you want to erect, whatever it may be, must somehow be constructed with these bricks, and with these alone.’

text: 6.372 Thus people today stop at the laws of nature, treating them as something inviolable, just as God and Fate were treated in past ages.
german: So bleiben sie bei den Naturgesetzen als bei etwas Unantastbarem stehen, wie die Älteren bei Gott und dem Schicksal.
english_ogden: So people stop short at natural laws as something unassailable, as did the ancients at God and Fate.
english_pears: Thus people today stop at the laws of nature, treating them as something inviolable, just as God and Fate were treated in past ages.

text: 6.373 The world is independent of my will.
german: Die Welt ist unabhängig von meinem Willen.
english_ogden: The world is independent of my will.
english_pears: The world is independent of my will.

text: 6.374 Even if all that we wish for were to happen, still this would only be a favour granted by fate, so to speak: for there is no logical connexion between the will and the world, which would guarantee it, and the supposed physical connexion itself is surely not something that we could will.
german: Auch wenn alles, was wir wünschen, geschähe, so wäre dies doch nur, sozusagen, eine Gnade des Schicksals, denn es ist kein logischer Zusammenhang zwischen Willen und Welt, der dies verbürgte, und den angenommenen physikalischen Zusammenhang könnten wir doch nicht selbst wieder wollen.
english_ogden: Even if everything we wished were to happen, this would only be, so to speak, a favour of fate, for there is no logical connexion between will and world, which would guarantee this, and the assumed physical connexion itself we could not again will.
english_pears: Even if all that we wish for were to happen, still this would only be a favour granted by fate, so to speak: for there is no logical connexion between the will and the world, which would guarantee it, and the supposed physical connexion itself is surely not something that we could will.

text: 6.375 Just as the only necessity that exists is logical necessity, so too the only impossibility that exists is logical impossibility.
german: Wie es nur eine logische Notwendigkeit gibt, so gibt es auch nur eine logische Unmöglichkeit.
english_ogden: As there is only a logical necessity, so there is only a logical impossibility.
english_pears: Just as the only necessity that exists is logical necessity, so too the only impossibility that exists is logical impossibility.

text: 6.3751 For example, the simultaneous presence of two colours at the same place in the visual field is impossible, in fact logically impossible, since it is ruled out by the logical structure of colour.
german: Dass z. B. zwei Farben zugleich an einem Ort des Gesichtsfeldes sind, ist unmöglich, und zwar logisch unmöglich, denn es ist durch die logische Struktur der Farbe ausgeschlossen.
english_ogden: For two colours, e.g. to be at one place in the visual field, is impossible, logically impossible, for it is excluded by the logical structure of colour.
english_pears: For example, the simultaneous presence of two colours at the same place in the visual field is impossible, in fact logically impossible, since it is ruled out by the logical structure of colour.

text: 6.4 All propositions are of equal value.
german: Alle Sätze sind gleichwertig.
english_ogden: All propositions are of equal value.
english_pears: All propositions are of equal value.

text: 6.41 The sense of the world must lie outside the world. In the world everything is as it is, and everything happens as it does happen: in it no value exists—and if it did exist, it would have no value.
german: Der Sinn der Welt muss außerhalb ihrer liegen. In der Welt ist alles, wie es ist, und geschieht alles, wie es geschieht; es gibt in ihr keinen Wert – und wenn es ihn gäbe, so hätte er keinen Wert.
english_ogden: The sense of the world must lie outside the world. In the world everything is as it is and happens as it does happen. In it there is no value—and if there were, it would be of no value.
english_pears: The sense of the world must lie outside the world. In the world everything is as it is, and everything happens as it does happen: in it no value exists—and if it did exist, it would have no value.

text: 6.42 So too it is impossible for there to be propositions of ethics.
german: Darum kann es auch keine Sätze der Ethik geben.
english_ogden: Hence also there can be no ethical propositions.
english_pears: So too it is impossible for there to be propositions of ethics.

text: 6.421 It is clear that ethics cannot be put into words.
german: Es ist klar, dass sich die Ethik nicht aussprechen lässt.
english_ogden: It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed.
english_pears: It is clear that ethics cannot be put into words.

text: 6.422 When an ethical law of the form, ‘Thou shalt …’ is laid down, one’s first thought is, ‘And what if I do not do it?’ It is clear, however, that ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the usual sense of the terms. So our question about the consequences of an action must be unimportant.—At least those consequences should not be events. For there must be something right about the question we posed. There must indeed be some kind of ethical reward and ethical punishment, but they must reside in the action itself.
german: Der erste Gedanke bei der Aufstellung eines ethischen Gesetzes von der Form „du sollst . . . .“ ist: Und was dann, wenn ich es nicht tue? Es ist aber klar, dass die Ethik nichts mit Strafe und Lohn im gewöhnlichen Sinne zu tun hat. Also muss diese Frage nach den Folgen einer Handlung belanglos sein. – Zum Mindesten dürfen diese Folgen nicht Ereignisse sein. Denn etwas muss doch an jener Fragestellung richtig sein. Es muss zwar eine Art von ethischem Lohn und ethischer Strafe geben, aber diese müssen in der Handlung selbst liegen.
english_ogden: The first thought in setting up an ethical law of the form “thou shalt …” is: And what if I do not do it? But it is clear that ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the ordinary sense. This question as to the consequences of an action must therefore be irrelevant. At least these consequences will not be events. For there must be something right in that formulation of the question. There must be some sort of ethical reward and ethical punishment, but this must lie in the action itself.
english_pears: When an ethical law of the form, ‘Thou shalt …’ is laid down, one’s first thought is, ‘And what if I do not do it?’ It is clear, however, that ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the usual sense of the terms. So our question about the consequences of an action must be unimportant.—At least those consequences should not be events. For there must be something right about the question we posed. There must indeed be some kind of ethical reward and ethical punishment, but they must reside in the action itself.

text: 6.423 It is impossible to speak about the will in so far as it is the subject of ethical attributes.
german: Vom Willen als dem Träger des Ethischen kann nicht gesprochen werden.
english_ogden: Of the will as the subject of the ethical we cannot speak.
english_pears: It is impossible to speak about the will in so far as it is the subject of ethical attributes.

text: 6.43 If the good or bad exercise of the will does alter the world, it can alter only the limits of the world, not the facts—not what can be expressed by means of language.
german: Wenn das gute oder böse Wollen die Welt ändert, so kann es nur die Grenzen der Welt ändern, nicht die Tatsachen; nicht das, was durch die Sprache ausgedrückt werden kann.
english_ogden: If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not the things that can be expressed in language.
english_pears: If the good or bad exercise of the will does alter the world, it can alter only the limits of the world, not the facts—not what can be expressed by means of language.

text: 6.431 So too at death the world does not alter, but comes to an end.
german: Wie auch beim Tod die Welt sich nicht ändert, sondern aufhört.
english_ogden: As in death, too, the world does not change, but ceases.
english_pears: So too at death the world does not alter, but comes to an end.

text: 6.4311 Death is not an event in life: we do not live to experience death.
german: Der Tod ist kein Ereignis des Lebens. Den Tod erlebt man nicht.
english_ogden: Death is not an event of life. Death is not lived through.
english_pears: Death is not an event in life: we do not live to experience death.

text: 6.4312 Not only is there no guarantee of the temporal immortality of the human soul, that is to say of its eternal survival after death; but, in any case, this assumption completely fails to accomplish the purpose for which it has always been intended. Or is some riddle solved by my surviving for ever? Is not this eternal life itself as much of a riddle as our present life? The solution of the riddle of life in space and time lies outside space and time.
german: Die zeitliche Unsterblichkeit der Seele des Menschen, das heißt also ihr ewiges Fortleben auch nach dem Tode, ist nicht nur auf keine Weise verbürgt, sondern vor allem leistet diese Annahme gar nicht das, was man immer mit ihr erreichen wollte. Wird denn dadurch ein Rätsel gelöst, dass ich ewig fortlebe? Ist denn dieses ewige Leben dann nicht ebenso rätselhaft wie das gegenwärtige? Die Lösung des Rätsels des Lebens in Raum und Zeit liegt außerhalb von Raum und Zeit.
english_ogden: The temporal immortality of the human soul, that is to say, its eternal survival also after death, is not only in no way guaranteed, but this assumption in the first place will not do for us what we always tried to make it do. Is a riddle solved by the fact that I survive for ever? Is this eternal life not as enigmatic as our present one? The solution of the riddle of life in space and time lies outside space and time.
english_pears: Not only is there no guarantee of the temporal immortality of the human soul, that is to say of its eternal survival after death; but, in any case, this assumption completely fails to accomplish the purpose for which it has always been intended. Or is some riddle solved by my surviving for ever? Is not this eternal life itself as much of a riddle as our present life? The solution of the riddle of life in space and time lies outside space and time.

text: 6.432 How things are in the world is a matter of complete indifference for what is higher. God does not reveal himself in the world.
german: Wie die Welt ist, ist für das Höhere vollkommen gleichgültig. Gott offenbart sich nicht in der Welt.
english_ogden: How the world is, is completely indifferent for what is higher. God does not reveal himself in the world.
english_pears: How things are in the world is a matter of complete indifference for what is higher. God does not reveal himself in the world.

text: 6.4321 The facts all contribute only to setting the problem, not to its solution.
german: Die Tatsachen gehören alle nur zur Aufgabe, nicht zur Lösung.
english_ogden: The facts all belong only to the task and not to its performance.
english_pears: The facts all contribute only to setting the problem, not to its solution.

text: 6.44 It is not how things are in the world that is mystical, but that it exists.
german: Nicht wie die Welt ist, ist das Mystische, sondern dass sie ist.
english_ogden: Not how the world is, is the mystical, but that it is.
english_pears: It is not how things are in the world that is mystical, but that it exists.

text: 6.45 To view the world sub specie aeterni is to view it as a whole—a limited whole.
german: Die Anschauung der Welt sub specie aeterni ist ihre Anschauung als – begrenztes – Ganzes.
english_ogden: The contemplation of the world sub specie aeterni is its contemplation as a limited whole.
english_pears: To view the world sub specie aeterni is to view it as a whole—a limited whole.

text: 6.5 When the answer cannot be put into words, neither can the question be put into words.
german: Zu einer Antwort, die man nicht aussprechen kann, kann man auch die Frage nicht aussprechen.
english_ogden: For an answer which cannot be expressed the question too cannot be expressed.
english_pears: When the answer cannot be put into words, neither can the question be put into words.

text: 6.51 Scepticism is not irrefutable, but obviously nonsensical, when it tries to raise doubts where no questions can be asked.
german: Skeptizismus ist nicht unwiderleglich, sondern offenbar unsinnig, wenn er bezweifeln will, wo nicht gefragt werden kann.
english_ogden: Scepticism is not irrefutable, but palpably senseless, if it would doubt where a question cannot be asked.
english_pears: Scepticism is not irrefutable, but obviously nonsensical, when it tries to raise doubts where no questions can be asked.

text: 6.52 We feel that even when all possible scientific questions have been answered, the problems of life remain completely untouched. Of course there are then no questions left, and this itself is the answer.
german: Wir fühlen, daß selbst, wenn alle möglichen wissenschaftlichen Fragen beantwortet sind, unsere Lebensprobleme noch gar nicht berührt sind. Freilich bleibt dann eben keine Frage mehr; und eben dies ist die Antwort.
english_ogden: We feel that even if all possible scientific questions be answered, the problems of life have still not been touched at all. Of course there is then no question left, and just this is the answer.
english_pears: We feel that even when all possible scientific questions have been answered, the problems of life remain completely untouched. Of course there are then no questions left, and this itself is the answer.

text: 6.521 The solution of the problem of life is seen in the vanishing of the problem.
german: Die Lösung des Problems des Lebens merkt man am Verschwinden dieses Problems.
english_ogden: The solution of the problem of life is seen in the vanishing of this problem.
english_pears: The solution of the problem of life is seen in the vanishing of the problem.

text: 6.522 There are, indeed, things that cannot be put into words. They make themselves manifest. They are what is mystical.
german: Es gibt allerdings Unaussprechliches. Dies zeigt sich, es ist das Mystische.
english_ogden: There is indeed the inexpressible. This shows itself; it is the mystical.
english_pears: There are, indeed, things that cannot be put into words. They make themselves manifest. They are what is mystical.

text: 6.53 The correct method in philosophy would really be the following: to say nothing except what can be said, i.e. propositions of natural science—i.e. something that has nothing to do with philosophy—and then, whenever someone else wanted to say something metaphysical, to demonstrate to him that he had failed to give a meaning to certain signs in his propositions. Although it would not be satisfying to the other person—he would not have the feeling that we were teaching him philosophy—this method would be the only strictly correct one.
german: Die richtige Methode der Philosophie wäre eigentlich die: Nichts zu sagen, als was sich sagen lässt, also Sätze der Naturwissenschaft – also etwas, was mit Philosophie nichts zu tun hat – , und dann immer, wenn ein anderer etwas Metaphysisches sagen wollte, ihm nachzuweisen, dass er gewissen Zeichen in seinen Sätzen keine Bedeutung gegeben hat. Diese Methode wäre für den anderen unbefriedigend – er hätte nicht das Gefühl, dass wir ihn Philosophie lehrten – aber sie wäre die einzig streng richtige.
english_ogden: The right method of philosophy would be this: To say nothing except what can be said, i.e. the propositions of natural science, i.e. something that has nothing to do with philosophy: and then always, when someone else wished to say something metaphysical, to demonstrate to him that he had given no meaning to certain signs in his propositions. This method would be unsatisfying to the other—he would not have the feeling that we were teaching him philosophy—but it would be the only strictly correct method.
english_pears: The correct method in philosophy would really be the following: to say nothing except what can be said, i.e. propositions of natural science—i.e. something that has nothing to do with philosophy—and then, whenever someone else wanted to say something metaphysical, to demonstrate to him that he had failed to give a meaning to certain signs in his propositions. Although it would not be satisfying to the other person—he would not have the feeling that we were teaching him philosophy—this method would be the only strictly correct one.

text: 6.54 My propositions serve as elucidations in the following way: anyone who understands me eventually recognizes them as nonsensical, when he has used them—as steps—to climb up beyond them. (He must, so to speak, throw away the ladder after he has climbed up it.)
german: Meine Sätze erläutern dadurch, dass sie der, welcher mich versteht, am Ende als unsinnig erkennt, wenn er durch sie – auf ihnen – über sie hinausgestiegen ist. (Er muss sozusagen die Leiter wegwerfen, nachdem er auf ihr hinaufgestiegen ist.)
english_ogden: My propositions are elucidatory in this way: he who understands me finally recognizes them as senseless, when he has climbed out through them, on them, over them. (He must so to speak throw away the ladder, after he has climbed up on it.)
english_pears: My propositions serve as elucidations in the following way: anyone who understands me eventually recognizes them as nonsensical, when he has used them—as steps—to climb up beyond them. (He must, so to speak, throw away the ladder after he has climbed up it.)

text: 7 What we cannot speak about we must pass over in silence.
german: Wovon man nicht sprechen kann, darüber muss man schweigen.
english_ogden: Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent.
english_pears: What we cannot speak about we must pass over in silence.
